poem.verse: 1The proverbs of Solomon son of David, king of Israel:
2For learning wisdom and discipline;

poetryblock.poem: for understanding insightful sayings;

poem.verse: 3for receiving prudent instruction

poetryblock.poem: in righteousness, justice, and integrity;

poem.verse: 4for teaching shrewdness to the inexperienced,

poetryblock.poem: knowledge and discretion to a young man –

poem.verse: 5let a wise person listen and increase learning,

poetryblock.poem: and let a discerning person obtain guidance –

poem.verse: 6for understanding a proverb or a parable,

poetryblock.poem: the words of the wise, and their riddles.

poem.verse: 7The fear of the Lord

poetryblock.poem: is the beginning of knowledge;
fools despise wisdom and discipline.

chapter.head1: Avoid the Path of the Violent

poem.verse: 8Listen, my son, to your father’s instruction,

poetryblock.poem: and don’t reject your mother’s teaching,

poem.verse: 9for they will be a garland of favour on your head

poetryblock.poem: and pendants round your neck.

poem.verse: 10My son, if sinners entice you,

poetryblock.poem: don’t be persuaded.

poem.verse: 11If they say ​– ​‘Come with us!

poetryblock.poem: Let’s set an ambush and kill someone.
Let’s attack some innocent person just for fun!

poem.verse: 12Let’s swallow them alive, like Sheol,

poetryblock.poem: whole, like those who go down to the Pit.

poem.verse: 13We’ll find all kinds of valuable property

poetryblock.poem: and fill our houses with plunder.

poem.verse: 14Throw in your lot with us,

poetryblock.poem: and we’ll all share the loot’ –

poem.verse: 15my son, don’t travel that road with them

poetryblock.poem: or set foot on their path,

poem.verse: 16because their feet run towards evil

poetryblock.poem: and they hurry to shed blood.

poem.verse: 17It is useless to spread a net

poetryblock.poem: where any bird can see it,

poem.verse: 18but they set an ambush to kill themselves;

poetryblock.poem: they attack their own lives.

poem.verse: 19Such are the paths of all who make profit dishonestly;

poetryblock.poem: it takes the lives of those who receive it.

poem.verse: 20Wisdom calls out in the street;

poetryblock.poem: she makes her voice heard in the public squares.

poem.verse: 21She cries out above the commotion;

poetryblock.poem: she speaks at the entrance of the city gates:

poem.verse: 22‘How long, inexperienced ones, will you love ignorance?

poetryblock.poem: How long will you mockers enjoy mocking
and you fools hate knowledge?

poem.verse: 23If you respond to my warning,

poetryblock.poem: then I will pour out my spirit on you
and teach you my words.

poem.verse: 24Since I called out and you refused,

poetryblock.poem: extended my hand and no one paid attention,

poem.verse: 25since you neglected all my counsel

poetryblock.poem: and did not accept my correction,

poem.verse: 26I, in turn, will laugh at your calamity.

poetryblock.poem: I will mock when terror strikes you,

poem.verse: 27when terror strikes you like a storm

poetryblock.poem: and your calamity comes like a whirlwind,
when trouble and stress overcome you.

poem.verse: 28Then they will call me, but I won’t answer;

poetryblock.poem: they will search for me, but won’t find me.

poem.verse: 29Because they hated knowledge,

poetryblock.poem: didn’t choose to fear the Lord,

poem.verse: 30were not interested in my counsel,

poetryblock.poem: and rejected all my correction,

poem.verse: 31they will eat the fruit of their way

poetryblock.poem: and be glutted with their own schemes.

poem.verse: 32For the apostasy of the inexperienced will kill them,

poetryblock.poem: and the complacency of fools will destroy them.

poem.verse: 33But whoever listens to me will live securely

poetryblock.poem: and be undisturbed by the dread of danger.’

poem.verse: 1My son, if you accept my words

poetryblock.poem: and store up my commands within you,

poem.verse: 2listening closely to wisdom

poetryblock.poem: and directing your heart to understanding;

poem.verse: 3furthermore, if you call out to insight

poetryblock.poem: and lift your voice to understanding,

poem.verse: 4if you seek it like silver

poetryblock.poem: and search for it like hidden treasure,

poem.verse: 5then you will understand the fear of the Lord

poetryblock.poem: and discover the knowledge of God.

poem.verse: 6For the Lord gives wisdom;

poetryblock.poem: from his mouth come knowledge and understanding.

poem.verse: 7He stores up success for the upright;

poetryblock.poem: He is a shield for those who live with integrity

poem.verse: 8so that he may guard the paths of justice

poetryblock.poem: and protect the way of his faithful followers.

poem.verse: 9Then you will understand righteousness, justice,

poetryblock.poem: and integrity ​– ​every good path.

poem.verse: 10For wisdom will enter your heart,

poetryblock.poem: and knowledge will delight you.

poem.verse: 11Discretion will watch over you,

poetryblock.poem: and understanding will guard you.

poem.verse: 12It will rescue you from the way of evil –

poetryblock.poem: from anyone who says perverse things,

poem.verse: 13from those who abandon the right paths

poetryblock.poem: to walk in ways of darkness,

poem.verse: 14from those who enjoy doing evil

poetryblock.poem: and celebrate perversion,

poem.verse: 15whose paths are crooked,

poetryblock.poem: and whose ways are devious.

poem.verse: 16It will rescue you from a forbidden woman,

poetryblock.poem: from a wayward woman with her flattering talk,

poem.verse: 17who abandons the companion of her youth

poetryblock.poem: and forgets the covenant of her God;

poem.verse: 18for her house sinks down to death

poetryblock.poem: and her ways to the land of the departed spirits.

poem.verse: 19None return who go to her;

poetryblock.poem: none reach the paths of life.

poem.verse: 20So follow the way of the good,

poetryblock.poem: and keep to the paths of the righteous.

poem.verse: 21For the upright will inhabit the land,

poetryblock.poem: and those of integrity will remain in it;

poem.verse: 22but the wicked will be cut off from the land,

poetryblock.poem: and the treacherous ripped out of it.

poem.verse: 1My son, don’t forget my teaching,

poetryblock.poem: but let your heart keep my commands;

poem.verse: 2for they will bring you

poetryblock.poem: many days, a full life, and well-being.

poem.verse: 3Never let loyalty and faithfulness leave you.

poetryblock.poem: Tie them round your neck;
write them on the tablet of your heart.

poem.verse: 4Then you will find favour and high regard

poetryblock.poem: with God and people.

poem.verse: 5Trust in the Lord with all your heart,

poetryblock.poem: and do not rely on your own understanding;

poem.verse: 6in all your ways know him,

poetryblock.poem: and he will make your paths straight.

poem.verse: 7Don’t be wise in your own eyes;

poetryblock.poem: fear the Lord and turn away from evil.

poem.verse: 8This will be healing for your body

poetryblock.poem: and strengthening for your bones.

poem.verse: 9Honour the Lord with your possessions

poetryblock.poem: and with the first produce of your entire harvest;

poem.verse: 10then your barns will be completely filled,

poetryblock.poem: and your vats will overflow with new wine.

poem.verse: 11Do not despise the Lord’s instruction, my son,

poetryblock.poem: and do not loathe his discipline;

poem.verse: 12for the Lord disciplines the one he loves,

poetryblock.poem: just as a father disciplines the son in whom he delights.

poem.verse: 13Happy is a man who finds wisdom

poetryblock.poem: and who acquires understanding,

poem.verse: 14for she is more profitable than silver,

poetryblock.poem: and her revenue is better than gold.

poem.verse: 15She is more precious than jewels;

poetryblock.poem: nothing you desire can equal her.

poem.verse: 16Long life is in her right hand;

poetryblock.poem: in her left, riches and honour.

poem.verse: 17Her ways are pleasant,

poetryblock.poem: and all her paths, peaceful.

poem.verse: 18She is a tree of life to those who embrace her,

poetryblock.poem: and those who hold on to her are happy.

poem.verse: 19The Lord founded the earth by wisdom

poetryblock.poem: and established the heavens by understanding.

poem.verse: 20By his knowledge the watery depths broke open,

poetryblock.poem: and the clouds dripped with dew.

poem.verse: 21Maintain sound wisdom and discretion.

poetryblock.poem: My son, don’t lose sight of them.

poem.verse: 22They will be life for you

poetryblock.poem: and adornment for your neck.

poem.verse: 23Then you will go safely on your way;

poetryblock.poem: your foot will not stumble.

poem.verse: 24When you lie down, you will not be afraid;

poetryblock.poem: you will lie down, and your sleep will be pleasant.

poem.verse: 25Don’t fear sudden danger

poetryblock.poem: or the ruin of the wicked when it comes,

poem.verse: 26for the Lord will be your confidence

poetryblock.poem: and will keep your foot from a snare.

poem.verse: 27When it is in your power,

poetryblock.poem: don’t withhold good from the one to whom it belongs.

poem.verse: 28Don’t say to your neighbour, ‘Go away! Come back later.

poetryblock.poem: I’ll give it tomorrow’ ​– ​when it is there with you.

poem.verse: 29Don’t plan any harm against your neighbour,

poetryblock.poem: for he trusts you and lives near you.

poem.verse: 30Don’t accuse anyone without cause,

poetryblock.poem: when he has done you no harm.

poem.verse: 31Don’t envy a violent man

poetryblock.poem: or choose any of his ways;

poem.verse: 32for the devious are detestable to the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: but he is a friend to the upright.

poem.verse: 33The Lord’s curse is on the household of the wicked,

poetryblock.poem: but he blesses the home of the righteous;

poem.verse: 34He mocks those who mock

poetryblock.poem: but gives grace to the humble.

poem.verse: 35The wise will inherit honour,

poetryblock.poem: but he holds up fools to dishonour.

poem.verse: 1Listen, sons, to a father’s discipline,

poetryblock.poem: and pay attention so that you may gain understanding,

poem.verse: 2for I am giving you good instruction.

poetryblock.poem: Don’t abandon my teaching.

poem.verse: 3When I was a son with my father,

poetryblock.poem: tender and precious to my mother,

poem.verse: 4he taught me and said,

poetryblock.poem: ‘Your heart must hold on to my words.
Keep my commands and live.

poem.verse: 5Get wisdom, get understanding;

poetryblock.poem: don’t forget or turn away from the words from my mouth.

poem.verse: 6Don’t abandon wisdom, and she will watch over you;

poetryblock.poem: love her, and she will guard you.

poem.verse: 7Wisdom is supreme ​– ​so get wisdom.

poetryblock.poem: And whatever else you get, get understanding.

poem.verse: 8Cherish her, and she will exalt you;

poetryblock.poem: if you embrace her, she will honour you.

poem.verse: 9She will place a garland of favour on your head;

poetryblock.poem: she will give you a crown of beauty.’

poem.verse: 10Listen, my son. Accept my words,

poetryblock.poem: and you will live many years.

poem.verse: 11I am teaching you the way of wisdom;

poetryblock.poem: I am guiding you on straight paths.

poem.verse: 12When you walk, your steps will not be hindered;

poetryblock.poem: when you run, you will not stumble.

poem.verse: 13Hold on to instruction; don’t let go.

poetryblock.poem: Guard it, for it is your life.

poem.verse: 14Keep off the path of the wicked;

poetryblock.poem: don’t proceed on the way of evil ones.

poem.verse: 15Avoid it; don’t travel on it.

poetryblock.poem: Turn away from it, and pass it by.

poem.verse: 16For they can’t sleep

poetryblock.poem: unless they have done what is evil;
they are robbed of sleep
unless they make someone stumble.

poem.verse: 17They eat the bread of wickedness

poetryblock.poem: and drink the wine of violence.

poem.verse: 18The path of the righteous is like the light of dawn,

poetryblock.poem: shining brighter and brighter until midday.

poem.verse: 19But the way of the wicked is like the darkest gloom;

poetryblock.poem: they don’t know what makes them stumble.

poem.verse: 20My son, pay attention to my words;

poetryblock.poem: listen closely to my sayings.

poem.verse: 21Don’t lose sight of them;

poetryblock.poem: keep them within your heart.

poem.verse: 22For they are life to those who find them,

poetryblock.poem: and health to one’s whole body.

poem.verse: 23Guard your heart above all else,

poetryblock.poem: for it is the source of life.

poem.verse: 24Don’t let your mouth speak dishonestly,

poetryblock.poem: and don’t let your lips talk deviously.

poem.verse: 25Let your eyes look forward;

poetryblock.poem: fix your gaze straight ahead.

poem.verse: 26Carefully consider the path for your feet,

poetryblock.poem: and all your ways will be established.

poem.verse: 27Don’t turn to the right or to the left;

poetryblock.poem: keep your feet away from evil.

poem.verse: 1My son, pay attention to my wisdom;

poetryblock.poem: listen closely to my understanding

poem.verse: 2so that you may maintain discretion

poetryblock.poem: and your lips safeguard knowledge.

poem.verse: 3Though the lips of the forbidden woman drip honey

poetryblock.poem: and her words are smoother than oil,

poem.verse: 4in the end she’s as bitter as wormwood

poetryblock.poem: and as sharp as a double-edged sword.

poem.verse: 5Her feet go down to death;

poetryblock.poem: her steps head straight for Sheol.

poem.verse: 6She doesn’t consider the path of life;

poetryblock.poem: she doesn’t know that her ways are unstable.

poem.verse: 7So now, sons, listen to me,

poetryblock.poem: and don’t turn away from the words from my mouth.

poem.verse: 8Keep your way far from her.

poetryblock.poem: Don’t go near the door of her house.

poem.verse: 9Otherwise, you will give up your vitality to others

poetryblock.poem: and your years to someone cruel;

poem.verse: 10strangers will drain your resources,

poetryblock.poem: and your hard-earned pay will end up in a foreigner’s house.

poem.verse: 11At the end of your life, you will lament

poetryblock.poem: when your physical body has been consumed,

poem.verse: 12and you will say, ‘How I hated discipline,

poetryblock.poem: and how my heart despised correction.

poem.verse: 13I didn’t obey my teachers

poetryblock.poem: or listen closely to my instructors.

poem.verse: 14I am on the verge of complete ruin

poetryblock.poem: before the entire community.’

poem.verse: 15Drink water from your own cistern,

poetryblock.poem: water flowing from your own well.

poem.verse: 16Should your springs flow in the streets,

poetryblock.poem: streams in the public squares?

poem.verse: 17They should be for you alone

poetryblock.poem: and not for you to share with strangers.

poem.verse: 18Let your fountain be blessed,

poetryblock.poem: and take pleasure in the wife of your youth.

poem.verse: 19A loving deer, a graceful doe –

poetryblock.poem: let her breasts always satisfy you;
be lost in her love for ever.

poem.verse: 20Why, my son, would you lose yourself

poetryblock.poem: with a forbidden woman
or embrace a wayward woman?

poem.verse: 21For a man’s ways are before the Lord’s eyes,

poetryblock.poem: and he considers all his paths.

poem.verse: 22A wicked man’s iniquities will trap him;

poetryblock.poem: he will become tangled in the ropes of his own sin.

poem.verse: 23He will die because there is no discipline,

poetryblock.poem: and be lost because of his great stupidity.

poem.verse: 1My son, if you have put up security for your neighbour

poetryblock.poem: or entered into an agreement with a stranger,

poem.verse: 2you have been snared by the words of your mouth –

poetryblock.poem: trapped by the words from your mouth.

poem.verse: 3Do this, then, my son, and free yourself,

poetryblock.poem: for you have put yourself in your neighbour’s power:
Go, humble yourself, and plead with your neighbour.

poem.verse: 4Don’t give sleep to your eyes

poetryblock.poem: or slumber to your eyelids.

poem.verse: 5Escape like a gazelle from a hunter,

poetryblock.poem: like a bird from a hunter’s trap.

poem.verse: 6Go to the ant, you slacker!

poetryblock.poem: Observe its ways and become wise.

poem.verse: 7Without leader, administrator, or ruler,
8it prepares its provisions in summer;

poetryblock.poem: it gathers its food during harvest.

poem.verse: 9How long will you stay in bed, you slacker?

poetryblock.poem: When will you get up from your sleep?

poem.verse: 10A little sleep, a little slumber,

poetryblock.poem: a little folding of the arms to rest,

poem.verse: 11and your poverty will come like a robber,

poetryblock.poem: your need, like a bandit.

poem.verse: 12A worthless person, a wicked man

poetryblock.poem: goes around speaking dishonestly,

poem.verse: 13winking his eyes, signalling with his feet,

poetryblock.poem: and gesturing with his fingers.

poem.verse: 14He always plots evil with perversity in his heart;

poetryblock.poem: he stirs up trouble.

poem.verse: 15Therefore calamity will strike him suddenly;

poetryblock.poem: he will be shattered instantly, beyond recovery.

poem.verse: 16The Lord hates six things;

poetryblock.poem: in fact, seven are detestable to him:

poem.verse: 17arrogant eyes, a lying tongue,

poetryblock.poem: hands that shed innocent blood,

poem.verse: 18a heart that plots wicked schemes,

poetryblock.poem: feet eager to run to evil,

poem.verse: 19a lying witness who gives false testimony,

poetryblock.poem: and one who stirs up trouble among brothers.

poem.verse: 20My son, keep your father’s command,

poetryblock.poem: and don’t reject your mother’s teaching.

poem.verse: 21Always bind them to your heart;

poetryblock.poem: tie them round your neck.

poem.verse: 22When you walk here and there, they will guide you;

poetryblock.poem: when you lie down, they will watch over you;
when you wake up, they will talk to you.

poem.verse: 23For a command is a lamp, teaching is a light,

poetryblock.poem: and corrective discipline is the way to life.

poem.verse: 24They will protect you from an evil woman,

poetryblock.poem: from the flattering tongue of a wayward woman.

poem.verse: 25Don’t lust in your heart for her beauty

poetryblock.poem: or let her captivate you with her eyelashes.

poem.verse: 26For a prostitute’s fee is only a loaf of bread,

poetryblock.poem: but the wife of another man goes after a precious life.

poem.verse: 27Can a man embrace fire

poetryblock.poem: and his clothes not be burned?

poem.verse: 28Can a man walk on burning coals

poetryblock.poem: without scorching his feet?

poem.verse: 29So it is with the one who sleeps with

poetryblock.poem: another man’s wife;
no one who touches her will go unpunished.

poem.verse: 30People don’t despise the thief if he steals

poetryblock.poem: to satisfy himself when he is hungry.

poem.verse: 31Still, if caught, he must pay seven times as much;

poetryblock.poem: he must give up all the wealth in his house.

poem.verse: 32The one who commits adultery lacks sense;

poetryblock.poem: whoever does so destroys himself.

poem.verse: 33He will get a beating and dishonour,

poetryblock.poem: and his disgrace will never be removed.

poem.verse: 34For jealousy enrages a husband,

poetryblock.poem: and he will show no mercy when he takes revenge.

poem.verse: 35He will not be appeased by anything

poetryblock.poem: or be persuaded by lavish bribes.

poem.verse: 1My son, obey my words,

poetryblock.poem: and treasure my commands.

poem.verse: 2Keep my commands and live,

poetryblock.poem: and guard my instructions
as you would the pupil of your eye.

poem.verse: 3Tie them to your fingers;

poetryblock.poem: write them on the tablet of your heart.

poem.verse: 4Say to wisdom, ‘You are my sister,’

poetryblock.poem: and call understanding your relative.

poem.verse: 5She will keep you from a forbidden woman,

poetryblock.poem: a wayward woman with her flattering talk.

poem.verse: 6At the window of my house

poetryblock.poem: I looked through my lattice.

poem.verse: 7I saw among the inexperienced,

poetryblock.poem: I noticed among the youths,
a young man lacking sense.

poem.verse: 8Crossing the street near her corner,

poetryblock.poem: he strolled down the road to her house

poem.verse: 9at twilight, in the evening,

poetryblock.poem: in the dark of the night.

poem.verse: 10A woman came to meet him

poetryblock.poem: dressed like a prostitute,
having a hidden agenda.

poem.verse: 11She is loud and defiant;

poetryblock.poem: her feet do not stay at home.

poem.verse: 12Now in the street, now in the squares,

poetryblock.poem: she lurks at every corner.

poem.verse: 13She grabs him and kisses him;

poetryblock.poem: she brazenly says to him,

poem.verse: 14‘I’ve made fellowship offerings;

poetryblock.poem: today I’ve fulfilled my vows.

poem.verse: 15So I came out to meet you,

poetryblock.poem: to search for you, and I’ve found you.

poem.verse: 16I’ve spread coverings on my bed –

poetryblock.poem: richly coloured linen from Egypt.

poem.verse: 17I’ve perfumed my bed

poetryblock.poem: with myrrh, aloes, and cinnamon.

poem.verse: 18Come, let’s drink deeply of lovemaking until morning.

poetryblock.poem: Let’s feast on each other’s love!

poem.verse: 19My husband isn’t home;

poetryblock.poem: he went on a long journey.

poem.verse: 20He took a bag of silver with him

poetryblock.poem: and will come home at the time of the full moon.’

poem.verse: 21She seduces him with her persistent pleading;

poetryblock.poem: she lures with her flattering talk.

poem.verse: 22He follows her impulsively

poetryblock.poem: like an ox going to the slaughter,
like a deer bounding towards a trap

poem.verse: 23until an arrow pierces its liver,

poetryblock.poem: like a bird darting into a snare –
he doesn’t know it will cost him his life.

poem.verse: 24Now, sons, listen to me,

poetryblock.poem: and pay attention to the words from my mouth.

poem.verse: 25Don’t let your heart turn aside to her ways;

poetryblock.poem: don’t stray onto her paths.

poem.verse: 26For she has brought many down to death;

poetryblock.poem: her victims are countless.

poem.verse: 27Her house is the road to Sheol,

poetryblock.poem: descending to the chambers of death.

poem.verse: 1Doesn’t wisdom call out?

poetryblock.poem: Doesn’t understanding make her voice heard?

poem.verse: 2At the heights overlooking the road,

poetryblock.poem: at the crossroads, she takes her stand.

poem.verse: 3Beside the gates leading into the city,

poetryblock.poem: at the main entrance, she cries out:

poem.verse: 4‘People, I call out to you;

poetryblock.poem: my cry is to the children of Adam.

poem.verse: 5Learn to be shrewd, you who are inexperienced;

poetryblock.poem: develop common sense, you who are foolish.

poem.verse: 6Listen, for I speak of noble things,

poetryblock.poem: and what my lips say is right.

poem.verse: 7For my mouth tells the truth,

poetryblock.poem: and wickedness is detestable to my lips.

poem.verse: 8All the words from my mouth are righteous;

poetryblock.poem: none of them are deceptive or perverse.

poem.verse: 9All of them are clear to the perceptive,

poetryblock.poem: and right to those who discover knowledge.

poem.verse: 10Accept my instruction instead of silver,

poetryblock.poem: and knowledge rather than pure gold.

poem.verse: 11For wisdom is better than jewels,

poetryblock.poem: and nothing desirable can equal it.

poem.verse: 12I, wisdom, share a home with shrewdness

poetryblock.poem: and have knowledge and discretion.

poem.verse: 13To fear the Lord is to hate evil.

poetryblock.poem: I hate arrogant pride, evil conduct,
and perverse speech.

poem.verse: 14I possess good advice and sound wisdom;

poetryblock.poem: I have understanding and strength.

poem.verse: 15It is by me that kings reign

poetryblock.poem: and rulers enact just law;

poem.verse: 16by me, princes lead,

poetryblock.poem: as do nobles and all righteous judges.

poem.verse: 17I love those who love me,

poetryblock.poem: and those who search for me find me.

poem.verse: 18With me are riches and honour,

poetryblock.poem: lasting wealth and righteousness.

poem.verse: 19My fruit is better than solid gold,

poetryblock.poem: and my harvest than pure silver.

poem.verse: 20I walk in the ways of righteousness,

poetryblock.poem: along the paths of justice,

poem.verse: 21giving wealth as an inheritance to those who love me,

poetryblock.poem: and filling their treasuries.

poem.verse: 22‘The Lord acquired me

poetryblock.poem: at the beginning of his creation,
before his works of long ago.

poem.verse: 23I was formed before ancient times,

poetryblock.poem: from the beginning, before the earth began.

poem.verse: 24I was born

poetryblock.poem: when there were no watery depths
and no springs filled with water.

poem.verse: 25Before the mountains were established,

poetryblock.poem: prior to the hills, I was given birth ​–

poem.verse: 26before he made the land, the fields,

poetryblock.poem: or the first soil on earth.

poem.verse: 27I was there when he established the heavens,

poetryblock.poem: when he laid out the horizon on the surface of the ocean,

poem.verse: 28when he placed the skies above,

poetryblock.poem: when the fountains of the ocean gushed out,

poem.verse: 29when he set a limit for the sea

poetryblock.poem: so that the waters would not violate his command,
when he laid out the foundations of the earth.

poem.verse: 30I was a skilled craftsman beside him.

poetryblock.poem: I was his delight every day,
always rejoicing before him.

poem.verse: 31I was rejoicing in his inhabited world,

poetryblock.poem: delighting in the children of Adam.

poem.verse: 32‘And now, sons, listen to me;

poetryblock.poem: those who keep my ways are happy.

poem.verse: 33Listen to instruction and be wise;

poetryblock.poem: don’t ignore it.

poem.verse: 34Anyone who listens to me is happy,

poetryblock.poem: watching at my doors every day,
waiting by the posts of my doorway.

poem.verse: 35For the one who finds me finds life

poetryblock.poem: and obtains favour from the Lord,

poem.verse: 36but the one who misses me harms himself;

poetryblock.poem: all who hate me love death.’

poem.verse: 1Wisdom has built her house;

poetryblock.poem: she has carved out her seven pillars.

poem.verse: 2She has prepared her meat; she has mixed her wine;

poetryblock.poem: she has also set her table.

poem.verse: 3She has sent out her female servants;

poetryblock.poem: she calls out from the highest points of the city:

poem.verse: 4‘Whoever is inexperienced, enter here! ’

poetryblock.poem: To the one who lacks sense, she says,

poem.verse: 5‘Come, eat my bread,

poetryblock.poem: and drink the wine I have mixed.

poem.verse: 6Leave inexperience behind, and you will live;

poetryblock.poem: pursue the way of understanding.

poem.verse: 7The one who corrects a mocker

poetryblock.poem: will bring abuse on himself;
the one who rebukes the wicked will get hurt.

poem.verse: 8Don’t rebuke a mocker, or he will hate you;

poetryblock.poem: rebuke the wise, and he will love you.

poem.verse: 9Instruct the wise, and he will be wiser still;

poetryblock.poem: teach the righteous, and he will learn more.

poem.verse: 10‘The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom,

poetryblock.poem: and the knowledge of the Holy One is understanding.

poem.verse: 11For by me your days will be many,

poetryblock.poem: and years will be added to your life.

poem.verse: 12If you are wise, you are wise for your own benefit;

poetryblock.poem: if you mock, you alone will bear the consequences.’

poem.verse: 13Folly is a rowdy woman;

poetryblock.poem: she is gullible and knows nothing.

poem.verse: 14She sits by the doorway of her house,

poetryblock.poem: on a seat at the highest point of the city,

poem.verse: 15calling to those who pass by,

poetryblock.poem: who go straight ahead on their paths:

poem.verse: 16‘Whoever is inexperienced, enter here! ’

poetryblock.poem: To the one who lacks sense, she says,

poem.verse: 17‘Stolen water is sweet,

poetryblock.poem: and bread eaten secretly is tasty! ’

poem.verse: 18But he doesn’t know that the departed spirits are there,

poetryblock.poem: that her guests are in the depths of Sheol.
A wise son brings joy to his father,
but a foolish son, heartache to his mother.

poem.verse: 2Ill-gotten gains do not profit anyone,

poetryblock.poem: but righteousness rescues from death.

poem.verse: 3The Lord will not let the righteous go hungry,

poetryblock.poem: but he denies the wicked what they crave.

poem.verse: 4Idle hands make one poor,

poetryblock.poem: but diligent hands bring riches.

poem.verse: 5The son who gathers during summer is prudent;

poetryblock.poem: the son who sleeps during harvest is disgraceful.

poem.verse: 6Blessings are on the head of the righteous,

poetryblock.poem: but the mouth of the wicked conceals violence.

poem.verse: 7The remembrance of the righteous is a blessing,

poetryblock.poem: but the name of the wicked will rot.

poem.verse: 8A wise heart accepts commands,

poetryblock.poem: but foolish lips will be destroyed.

poem.verse: 9The one who lives with integrity lives securely,

poetryblock.poem: but whoever perverts his ways will be found out.

poem.verse: 10A sly wink of the eye causes grief,

poetryblock.poem: and foolish lips will be destroyed.

poem.verse: 11The mouth of the righteous is a fountain of life,

poetryblock.poem: but the mouth of the wicked conceals violence.

poem.verse: 12Hatred stirs up conflicts,

poetryblock.poem: but love covers all offences.

poem.verse: 13Wisdom is found on the lips of the discerning,

poetryblock.poem: but a rod is for the back of the one who lacks sense.

poem.verse: 14The wise store up knowledge,

poetryblock.poem: but the mouth of the fool hastens destruction.

poem.verse: 15The wealth of the rich is his fortified city;

poetryblock.poem: the poverty of the poor is their destruction.

poem.verse: 16The reward of the righteous is life;

poetryblock.poem: the wages of the wicked is punishment.

poem.verse: 17The one who follows instruction is on the path to life,

poetryblock.poem: but the one who rejects correction goes astray.

poem.verse: 18The one who conceals hatred has lying lips,

poetryblock.poem: and whoever spreads slander is a fool.

poem.verse: 19When there are many words, sin is unavoidable,

poetryblock.poem: but the one who controls his lips is prudent.

poem.verse: 20The tongue of the righteous is pure silver;

poetryblock.poem: the heart of the wicked is of little value.

poem.verse: 21The lips of the righteous feed many,

poetryblock.poem: but fools die for lack of sense.

poem.verse: 22The Lord’s blessing enriches,

poetryblock.poem: and he adds no painful effort to it.

poem.verse: 23As shameful conduct is pleasure for a fool,

poetryblock.poem: so wisdom is for a person of understanding.

poem.verse: 24What the wicked dreads will come to him,

poetryblock.poem: but what the righteous desire will be given to them.

poem.verse: 25When the whirlwind passes,

poetryblock.poem: the wicked are no more,
but the righteous are secure for ever.

poem.verse: 26Like vinegar to the teeth and smoke to the eyes,

poetryblock.poem: so the slacker is to the one who sends him on an errand.

poem.verse: 27The fear of the Lord prolongs life,

poetryblock.poem: but the years of the wicked are cut short.

poem.verse: 28The hope of the righteous is joy,

poetryblock.poem: but the expectation of the wicked will perish.

poem.verse: 29The way of the Lord is a stronghold for the honourable,

poetryblock.poem: but destruction awaits evildoers.

poem.verse: 30The righteous will never be shaken,

poetryblock.poem: but the wicked will not remain on the earth.

poem.verse: 31The mouth of the righteous produces wisdom,

poetryblock.poem: but a perverse tongue will be cut out.

poem.verse: 32The lips of the righteous know what is appropriate,

poetryblock.poem: but the mouth of the wicked, only what is perverse.

poem.verse: 1Dishonest scales are detestable to the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: but an accurate weight is his delight.

poem.verse: 2When arrogance comes, disgrace follows,

poetryblock.poem: but with humility comes wisdom.

poem.verse: 3The integrity of the upright guides them,

poetryblock.poem: but the perversity of the treacherous destroys them.

poem.verse: 4Wealth is not profitable on a day of wrath,

poetryblock.poem: but righteousness rescues from death.

poem.verse: 5The righteousness of the blameless clears his path,

poetryblock.poem: but the wicked person will fall because of his wickedness.

poem.verse: 6The righteousness of the upright rescues them,

poetryblock.poem: but the treacherous are trapped by their own desires.

poem.verse: 7When the wicked person dies,

poetryblock.poem: his expectation comes to nothing,
and hope placed in wealth vanishes.

poem.verse: 8The righteous one is rescued from trouble;

poetryblock.poem: in his place, the wicked one goes in.

poem.verse: 9With his mouth the ungodly destroys his neighbour,

poetryblock.poem: but through knowledge the righteous are rescued.

poem.verse: 10When the righteous thrive, a city rejoices;

poetryblock.poem: when the wicked die, there is joyful shouting.

poem.verse: 11A city is built up by the blessing of the upright,

poetryblock.poem: but it is torn down by the mouth of the wicked.

poem.verse: 12Whoever shows contempt for his neighbour lacks sense,

poetryblock.poem: but a person with understanding keeps silent.

poem.verse: 13A gossip goes around revealing a secret,

poetryblock.poem: but a trustworthy person keeps a confidence.

poem.verse: 14Without guidance, a people will fall,

poetryblock.poem: but with many counsellors there is deliverance.

poem.verse: 15If someone puts up security for a stranger,

poetryblock.poem: he will suffer for it,
but the one who hates such agreements is protected.

poem.verse: 16A gracious woman gains honour,

poetryblock.poem: but violent people gain only riches.

poem.verse: 17A kind man benefits himself,

poetryblock.poem: but a cruel person brings ruin on himself.

poem.verse: 18The wicked person earns an empty wage,

poetryblock.poem: but the one who sows righteousness, a true reward.

poem.verse: 19Genuine righteousness leads to life,

poetryblock.poem: but pursuing evil leads to death.

poem.verse: 20Those with twisted minds are detestable to the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: but those with blameless conduct are his delight.

poem.verse: 21Be assured that a wicked person

poetryblock.poem: will not go unpunished,
but the offspring of the righteous will escape.

poem.verse: 22A beautiful woman who rejects good sense

poetryblock.poem: is like a gold ring in a pig’s snout.

poem.verse: 23The desire of the righteous turns out well,

poetryblock.poem: but the hope of the wicked leads to wrath.

poem.verse: 24One person gives freely,

poetryblock.poem: yet gains more;
another withholds what is right,
only to become poor.

poem.verse: 25A generous person will be enriched,

poetryblock.poem: and the one who gives a drink of water
will receive water.

poem.verse: 26People will curse anyone who hoards grain,

poetryblock.poem: but a blessing will come to the one who sells it.

poem.verse: 27The one who searches for what is good seeks favour,

poetryblock.poem: but if someone looks for trouble, it will come to him.

poem.verse: 28Anyone trusting in his riches will fall,

poetryblock.poem: but the righteous will flourish like foliage.

poem.verse: 29The one who brings ruin on his household

poetryblock.poem: will inherit the wind,
and a fool will be a slave
to someone whose heart is wise.

poem.verse: 30The fruit of the righteous is a tree of life,

poetryblock.poem: but a cunning person takes lives.

poem.verse: 31If the righteous will be repaid on earth,

poetryblock.poem: how much more the wicked and sinful.

poem.verse: 1Whoever loves discipline loves knowledge,

poetryblock.poem: but one who hates correction is stupid.

poem.verse: 2One who is good obtains favour from the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: but he condemns a person who schemes.

poem.verse: 3No one can be made secure by wickedness,

poetryblock.poem: but the root of the righteous is immovable.

poem.verse: 4A wife of noble character is her husband’s crown,

poetryblock.poem: but a wife who causes shame
is like rottenness in his bones.

poem.verse: 5The thoughts of the righteous are just,

poetryblock.poem: but guidance from the wicked is deceitful.

poem.verse: 6The words of the wicked are a deadly ambush,

poetryblock.poem: but the speech of the upright rescues them.

poem.verse: 7The wicked are overthrown and perish,

poetryblock.poem: but the house of the righteous will stand.

poem.verse: 8A man is praised for his insight,

poetryblock.poem: but a twisted mind is despised.

poem.verse: 9Better to be disregarded, yet have a servant,

poetryblock.poem: than to act important but have no food.

poem.verse: 10The righteous cares about his animal’s health,

poetryblock.poem: but even the merciful acts of the wicked are cruel.

poem.verse: 11The one who works his land will have plenty of food,

poetryblock.poem: but whoever chases fantasies lacks sense.

poem.verse: 12The wicked desire what evil people have caught,

poetryblock.poem: but the root of the righteous is productive.

poem.verse: 13By rebellious speech an evil person is trapped,

poetryblock.poem: but a righteous person escapes from trouble.

poem.verse: 14A person will be satisfied with good

poetryblock.poem: by the fruit of his mouth,
and the work of a person’s hands will reward him.

poem.verse: 15A fool’s way is right in his own eyes,

poetryblock.poem: but whoever listens to counsel is wise.

poem.verse: 16A fool’s displeasure is known at once,

poetryblock.poem: but whoever ignores an insult is sensible.

poem.verse: 17Whoever speaks the truth declares what is right,

poetryblock.poem: but a false witness speaks deceit.

poem.verse: 18There is one who speaks rashly,

poetryblock.poem: like a piercing sword;
but the tongue of the wise brings healing.

poem.verse: 19Truthful lips endure for ever,

poetryblock.poem: but a lying tongue, only a moment.

poem.verse: 20Deceit is in the hearts of those who plot evil,

poetryblock.poem: but those who promote peace have joy.

poem.verse: 21No disaster overcomes the righteous,

poetryblock.poem: but the wicked are full of misery.

poem.verse: 22Lying lips are detestable to the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: but faithful people are his delight.

poem.verse: 23A shrewd person conceals knowledge,

poetryblock.poem: but a foolish heart publicises stupidity.

poem.verse: 24The diligent hand will rule,

poetryblock.poem: but laziness will lead to forced labour.

poem.verse: 25Anxiety in a person’s heart weighs it down,

poetryblock.poem: but a good word cheers it up.

poem.verse: 26A righteous person is careful in dealing with his neighbour,

poetryblock.poem: but the ways of the wicked lead them astray.

poem.verse: 27A lazy hunter doesn’t roast his game,

poetryblock.poem: but to a diligent person, his wealth is precious.

poem.verse: 28There is life in the path of righteousness,

poetryblock.poem: and in its path there is no death.

poem.verse: 1A wise son responds to his father’s discipline,

poetryblock.poem: but a mocker doesn’t listen to rebuke.

poem.verse: 2From the fruit of his mouth,

poetryblock.poem: a person will enjoy good things,
but treacherous people have an appetite for violence.

poem.verse: 3The one who guards his mouth protects his life;

poetryblock.poem: the one who opens his lips invites his own ruin.

poem.verse: 4The slacker craves, yet has nothing,

poetryblock.poem: but the diligent is fully satisfied.

poem.verse: 5The righteous hate lying,

poetryblock.poem: but the wicked bring disgust and shame.

poem.verse: 6Righteousness guards people of integrity,

poetryblock.poem: but wickedness undermines the sinner.

poem.verse: 7One person pretends to be rich but has nothing;

poetryblock.poem: another pretends to be poor but has abundant wealth.

poem.verse: 8Riches are a ransom for a person’s life,

poetryblock.poem: but a poor person hears no threat.

poem.verse: 9The light of the righteous shines brightly,

poetryblock.poem: but the lamp of the wicked is put out.

poem.verse: 10Arrogance leads to nothing but strife,

poetryblock.poem: but wisdom is gained by those who take advice.

poem.verse: 11Wealth obtained by fraud will dwindle,

poetryblock.poem: but whoever earns it through labour will multiply it.

poem.verse: 12Hope delayed makes the heart sick,

poetryblock.poem: but desire fulfilled is a tree of life.

poem.verse: 13The one who has contempt for instruction will pay the penalty,

poetryblock.poem: but the one who respects a command will be rewarded.

poem.verse: 14A wise person’s instruction is a fountain of life,

poetryblock.poem: turning people away from the snares of death.

poem.verse: 15Good sense wins favour,

poetryblock.poem: but the way of the treacherous never changes.

poem.verse: 16Every sensible person acts knowledgeably,

poetryblock.poem: but a fool displays his stupidity.

poem.verse: 17A wicked envoy falls into trouble,

poetryblock.poem: but a trustworthy courier brings healing.

poem.verse: 18Poverty and disgrace come to those

poetryblock.poem: who ignore discipline,
but the one who accepts correction will be honoured.

poem.verse: 19Desire fulfilled is sweet to the taste,

poetryblock.poem: but to turn from evil is detestable to fools.

poem.verse: 20The one who walks with the wise will become wise,

poetryblock.poem: but a companion of fools will suffer harm.

poem.verse: 21Disaster pursues sinners,

poetryblock.poem: but good rewards the righteous.

poem.verse: 22A good man leaves an inheritance to his grandchildren,

poetryblock.poem: but the sinner’s wealth is stored up for the righteous.

poem.verse: 23The uncultivated field of the poor yields abundant food,

poetryblock.poem: but without justice, it is swept away.

poem.verse: 24The one who will not use the rod hates his son,

poetryblock.poem: but the one who loves him disciplines him diligently.

poem.verse: 25A righteous person eats until he is satisfied,

poetryblock.poem: but the stomach of the wicked is empty.

poem.verse: 1Every wise woman builds her house,

poetryblock.poem: but a foolish one tears it down with her own hands.

poem.verse: 2Whoever lives with integrity fears the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: but the one who is devious in his ways despises him.

poem.verse: 3The proud speech of a fool brings a rod of discipline,

poetryblock.poem: but the lips of the wise protect them.

poem.verse: 4Where there are no oxen, the feeding trough is empty,

poetryblock.poem: but an abundant harvest comes through the strength of an ox.

poem.verse: 5An honest witness does not deceive,

poetryblock.poem: but a dishonest witness utters lies.

poem.verse: 6A mocker seeks wisdom and doesn’t find it,

poetryblock.poem: but knowledge comes easily to the perceptive.

poem.verse: 7Stay away from a foolish person;

poetryblock.poem: you will gain no knowledge from his speech.

poem.verse: 8The sensible person’s wisdom is to consider his way,

poetryblock.poem: but the stupidity of fools deceives them.

poem.verse: 9Fools mock at making reparation,

poetryblock.poem: but there is goodwill among the upright.

poem.verse: 10The heart knows its own bitterness,

poetryblock.poem: and no outsider shares in its joy.

poem.verse: 11The house of the wicked will be destroyed,

poetryblock.poem: but the tent of the upright will flourish.

poem.verse: 12There is a way that seems right to a person,

poetryblock.poem: but its end is the way to death.

poem.verse: 13Even in laughter a heart may be sad,

poetryblock.poem: and joy may end in grief.

poem.verse: 14The disloyal one will get what his conduct deserves,

poetryblock.poem: and a good one, what his deeds deserve.

poem.verse: 15The inexperienced one believes anything,

poetryblock.poem: but the sensible one watches his steps.

poem.verse: 16A wise person is cautious and turns from evil,

poetryblock.poem: but a fool is easily angered and is careless.

poem.verse: 17A quick-tempered person acts foolishly,

poetryblock.poem: and one who schemes is hated.

poem.verse: 18The inexperienced inherit foolishness,

poetryblock.poem: but the sensible are crowned with knowledge.

poem.verse: 19The evil bow before those who are good,

poetryblock.poem: and the wicked, at the gates of the righteous.

poem.verse: 20A poor person is hated even by his neighbour,

poetryblock.poem: but there are many who love the rich.

poem.verse: 21The one who despises his neighbour sins,

poetryblock.poem: but whoever shows kindness to the poor will be happy.

poem.verse: 22Don’t those who plan evil go astray?

poetryblock.poem: But those who plan good find loyalty and faithfulness.

poem.verse: 23There is profit in all hard work,

poetryblock.poem: but endless talk leads only to poverty.

poem.verse: 24The crown of the wise is their wealth,

poetryblock.poem: but the foolishness of fools produces foolishness.

poem.verse: 25A truthful witness rescues lives,

poetryblock.poem: but one who utters lies is deceitful.

poem.verse: 26In the fear of the Lord one has strong confidence

poetryblock.poem: and his children have a refuge.

poem.verse: 27The fear of the Lord is a fountain of life,

poetryblock.poem: turning people away from the snares of death.

poem.verse: 28A large population is a king’s splendour,

poetryblock.poem: but a shortage of people is a ruler’s devastation.

poem.verse: 29A patient person shows great understanding,

poetryblock.poem: but a quick-tempered one promotes foolishness.

poem.verse: 30A tranquil heart is life to the body,

poetryblock.poem: but jealousy is rottenness to the bones.

poem.verse: 31The one who oppresses the poor person insults his Maker,

poetryblock.poem: but one who is kind to the needy honours him.

poem.verse: 32The wicked one is thrown down by his own sin,

poetryblock.poem: but the righteous one has a refuge in his death.

poem.verse: 33Wisdom resides in the heart of the discerning;

poetryblock.poem: she is known even among fools.

poem.verse: 34Righteousness exalts a nation,

poetryblock.poem: but sin is a disgrace to any people.

poem.verse: 35A king favours a prudent servant,

poetryblock.poem: but his anger falls on a disgraceful one.

poem.verse: 1A gentle answer turns away anger,

poetryblock.poem: but a harsh word stirs up wrath.

poem.verse: 2The tongue of the wise makes knowledge attractive,

poetryblock.poem: but the mouth of fools blurts out foolishness.

poem.verse: 3The eyes of the Lord are everywhere,

poetryblock.poem: observing the wicked and the good.

poem.verse: 4The tongue that heals is a tree of life,

poetryblock.poem: but a devious tongue breaks the spirit.

poem.verse: 5A fool despises his father’s discipline,

poetryblock.poem: but a person who accepts correction is sensible.

poem.verse: 6The house of the righteous has great wealth,

poetryblock.poem: but trouble accompanies the income of the wicked.

poem.verse: 7The lips of the wise broadcast knowledge,

poetryblock.poem: but not so the heart of fools.

poem.verse: 8The sacrifice of the wicked is detestable to the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: but the prayer of the upright is his delight.

poem.verse: 9The Lord detests the way of the wicked,

poetryblock.poem: but he loves the one who pursues righteousness.

poem.verse: 10Discipline is harsh for the one who leaves the path;

poetryblock.poem: the one who hates correction will die.

poem.verse: 11Sheol and Abaddon lie open before the Lord –

poetryblock.poem: how much more, human hearts.

poem.verse: 12A mocker doesn’t love one who corrects him;

poetryblock.poem: he will not consult the wise.

poem.verse: 13A joyful heart makes a face cheerful,

poetryblock.poem: but a sad heart produces a broken spirit.

poem.verse: 14A discerning mind seeks knowledge,

poetryblock.poem: but the mouth of fools feeds on foolishness.

poem.verse: 15All the days of the oppressed are miserable,

poetryblock.poem: but a cheerful heart has a continual feast.

poem.verse: 16Better a little with the fear of the Lord

poetryblock.poem: than great treasure with turmoil.

poem.verse: 17Better a meal of vegetables where there is love

poetryblock.poem: than a fattened ox with hatred.

poem.verse: 18A hot-tempered person stirs up conflict,

poetryblock.poem: but one slow to anger calms strife.

poem.verse: 19A slacker’s way is like a thorny hedge,

poetryblock.poem: but the path of the upright is a raised road.

poem.verse: 20A wise son brings joy to his father,

poetryblock.poem: but a foolish man despises his mother.

poem.verse: 21Foolishness brings joy to one without sense,

poetryblock.poem: but a person with understanding walks a straight path.

poem.verse: 22Plans fail when there is no counsel,

poetryblock.poem: but with many advisers they succeed.

poem.verse: 23A person takes joy in giving an answer;

poetryblock.poem: and a timely word ​– ​how good that is!

poem.verse: 24For the prudent the path of life leads upwards,

poetryblock.poem: so that he may avoid going down to Sheol.

poem.verse: 25The Lord tears apart the house of the proud,

poetryblock.poem: but he protects the widow’s territory.

poem.verse: 26The Lord detests the plans of the one who is evil,

poetryblock.poem: but pleasant words are pure.

poem.verse: 27The one who profits dishonestly troubles his household,

poetryblock.poem: but the one who hates bribes will live.

poem.verse: 28The mind of the righteous person thinks before answering,

poetryblock.poem: but the mouth of the wicked blurts out evil things.

poem.verse: 29The Lord is far from the wicked,

poetryblock.poem: but he hears the prayer of the righteous.

poem.verse: 30Bright eyes cheer the heart;

poetryblock.poem: good news strengthens the bones.

poem.verse: 31One who listens to life-giving rebukes

poetryblock.poem: will be at home among the wise.

poem.verse: 32Anyone who ignores discipline despises himself,

poetryblock.poem: but whoever listens to correction acquires good sense.

poem.verse: 33The fear of the Lord is what wisdom teaches,

poetryblock.poem: and humility comes before honour.

poem.verse: 1The reflections of the heart belong to mankind,

poetryblock.poem: but the answer of the tongue is from the Lord.

poem.verse: 2All a person’s ways seem right to him,

poetryblock.poem: but the Lord weighs motives.

poem.verse: 3Commit your activities to the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: and your plans will be established.

poem.verse: 4The Lord has prepared everything for his purpose –

poetryblock.poem: even the wicked for the day of disaster.

poem.verse: 5Everyone with a proud heart is detestable to the Lord;

poetryblock.poem: be assured, he will not go unpunished.

poem.verse: 6Iniquity is atoned for by loyalty and faithfulness,

poetryblock.poem: and one turns from evil by the fear of the Lord.

poem.verse: 7When a person’s ways please the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: he makes even his enemies to be at peace with him.

poem.verse: 8Better a little with righteousness

poetryblock.poem: than great income with injustice.

poem.verse: 9A person’s heart plans his way,

poetryblock.poem: but the Lord determines his steps.

poem.verse: 10God’s verdict is on the lips of a king;

poetryblock.poem: his mouth should not give an unfair judgement.

poem.verse: 11Honest balances and scales are the Lord’s;

poetryblock.poem: all the weights in the bag are his concern.

poem.verse: 12Wicked behaviour is detestable to kings,

poetryblock.poem: since a throne is established through righteousness.

poem.verse: 13Righteous lips are a king’s delight,

poetryblock.poem: and he loves one who speaks honestly.

poem.verse: 14A king’s fury is a messenger of death,

poetryblock.poem: but a wise person appeases it.

poem.verse: 15When a king’s face lights up, there is life;

poetryblock.poem: his favour is like a cloud with spring rain.

poem.verse: 16Get wisdom –

poetryblock.poem: how much better it is than gold!
And get understanding –
it is preferable to silver.

poem.verse: 17The road of the upright avoids evil;

poetryblock.poem: the one who guards his way protects his life.

poem.verse: 18Pride comes before destruction,

poetryblock.poem: and an arrogant spirit before a fall.

poem.verse: 19Better to be lowly of spirit with the humble

poetryblock.poem: than to divide plunder with the proud.

poem.verse: 20The one who understands a matter finds success,

poetryblock.poem: and the one who trusts in the Lord will be happy.

poem.verse: 21Anyone with a wise heart is called discerning,

poetryblock.poem: and pleasant speech increases learning.

poem.verse: 22Insight is a fountain of life for its possessor,

poetryblock.poem: but the discipline of fools is folly.

poem.verse: 23The heart of a wise person instructs his mouth;

poetryblock.poem: it adds learning to his speech.

poem.verse: 24Pleasant words are a honeycomb:

poetryblock.poem: sweet to the taste and health to the body.

poem.verse: 25There is a way that seems right to a person,

poetryblock.poem: but its end is the way to death.

poem.verse: 26A worker’s appetite works for him

poetryblock.poem: because his hunger urges him on.

poem.verse: 27A worthless person digs up evil,

poetryblock.poem: and his speech is like a scorching fire.

poem.verse: 28A contrary person spreads conflict,

poetryblock.poem: and a gossip separates close friends.

poem.verse: 29A violent person lures his neighbour,

poetryblock.poem: leading him on a path that is not good.

poem.verse: 30The one who narrows his eyes is planning deceptions;

poetryblock.poem: the one who compresses his lips brings about evil.

poem.verse: 31Grey hair is a glorious crown;

poetryblock.poem: it is found in the ways of righteousness.

poem.verse: 32Patience is better than power,

poetryblock.poem: and controlling one’s emotions, than capturing a city.

poem.verse: 33The lot is cast into the lap,

poetryblock.poem: but its every decision is from the Lord.

poem.verse: 1Better a dry crust with peace

poetryblock.poem: than a house full of feasting with strife.

poem.verse: 2A prudent servant will rule over a disgraceful son

poetryblock.poem: and share an inheritance among brothers.

poem.verse: 3A crucible for silver, and a smelter for gold,

poetryblock.poem: and the Lord is the tester of hearts.

poem.verse: 4A wicked person listens to malicious talk;

poetryblock.poem: a liar pays attention to a destructive tongue.

poem.verse: 5The one who mocks the poor insults his Maker,

poetryblock.poem: and one who rejoices over calamity
will not go unpunished.

poem.verse: 6Grandchildren are the crown of the elderly,

poetryblock.poem: and the pride of children is their fathers.

poem.verse: 7Eloquent words are not appropriate on a fool’s lips;

poetryblock.poem: how much worse are lies for a ruler.

poem.verse: 8A bribe seems like a magic stone to its owner;

poetryblock.poem: wherever he turns, he succeeds.

poem.verse: 9Whoever conceals an offence promotes love,

poetryblock.poem: but whoever gossips about it separates friends.

poem.verse: 10A rebuke cuts into a perceptive person

poetryblock.poem: more than a hundred lashes into a fool.

poem.verse: 11An evil person desires only rebellion;

poetryblock.poem: a cruel messenger will be sent against him.

poem.verse: 12Better for a person to meet a bear robbed of her cubs

poetryblock.poem: than a fool in his foolishness.

poem.verse: 13If anyone returns evil for good,

poetryblock.poem: evil will never depart from his house.

poem.verse: 14To start a conflict is to release a flood;

poetryblock.poem: stop the dispute before it breaks out.

poem.verse: 15Acquitting the guilty and condemning the just –

poetryblock.poem: both are detestable to the Lord.

poem.verse: 16Why does a fool have money in his hand

poetryblock.poem: with no intention of buying wisdom?

poem.verse: 17A friend loves at all times,

poetryblock.poem: and a brother is born for a difficult time.

poem.verse: 18One without sense enters an agreement

poetryblock.poem: and puts up security for his friend.

poem.verse: 19One who loves to offend loves strife;

poetryblock.poem: one who builds a high threshold invites injury.

poem.verse: 20One with a twisted mind will not succeed,

poetryblock.poem: and one with deceitful speech will fall into ruin.

poem.verse: 21A man fathers a fool to his own sorrow;

poetryblock.poem: the father of a fool has no joy.

poem.verse: 22A joyful heart is good medicine,

poetryblock.poem: but a broken spirit dries up the bones.

poem.verse: 23A wicked person secretly takes a bribe

poetryblock.poem: to subvert the course of justice.

poem.verse: 24Wisdom is the focus of the perceptive,

poetryblock.poem: but a fool’s eyes roam to the ends of the earth.

poem.verse: 25A foolish son is grief to his father

poetryblock.poem: and bitterness to the one who bore him.

poem.verse: 26It is certainly not good to fine an innocent person

poetryblock.poem: or to beat a noble for his honesty.

poem.verse: 27The one who has knowledge restrains his words,

poetryblock.poem: and one who keeps a cool head
is a person of understanding.

poem.verse: 28Even a fool is considered wise when he keeps silent ​–

poetryblock.poem: discerning, when he seals his lips.

poem.verse: 1One who isolates himself pursues selfish desires;

poetryblock.poem: he rebels against all sound wisdom.

poem.verse: 2A fool does not delight in understanding,

poetryblock.poem: but only wants to show off his opinions.

poem.verse: 3When a wicked person comes, contempt also comes,

poetryblock.poem: and along with dishonour, derision.

poem.verse: 4The words of a person’s mouth are deep waters,

poetryblock.poem: a flowing river, a fountain of wisdom.

poem.verse: 5It is not good to show partiality to the guilty,

poetryblock.poem: denying an innocent person justice.

poem.verse: 6A fool’s lips lead to strife,

poetryblock.poem: and his mouth provokes a beating.

poem.verse: 7A fool’s mouth is his devastation,

poetryblock.poem: and his lips are a trap for his life.

poem.verse: 8A gossip’s words are like delicacies

poetryblock.poem: that go down to one’s innermost being.

poem.verse: 9The one who is lazy in his work

poetryblock.poem: is brother to a vandal.

poem.verse: 10The name of the Lord is a strong tower;

poetryblock.poem: the righteous run to it and are protected.

poem.verse: 11The wealth of the rich is his fortified city;

poetryblock.poem: in his imagination it is like a high wall.

poem.verse: 12Before his downfall a person’s heart is proud,

poetryblock.poem: but humility comes before honour.

poem.verse: 13The one who gives an answer before he listens –

poetryblock.poem: this is foolishness and disgrace for him.

poem.verse: 14A person’s spirit can endure sickness,

poetryblock.poem: but who can survive a broken spirit?

poem.verse: 15The mind of the discerning acquires knowledge,

poetryblock.poem: and the ear of the wise seeks it.

poem.verse: 16A person’s gift opens doors for him

poetryblock.poem: and brings him before the great.

poem.verse: 17The first to state his case seems right

poetryblock.poem: until another comes and cross-examines him.

poem.verse: 18Casting the lot ends quarrels

poetryblock.poem: and separates powerful opponents.

poem.verse: 19An offended brother is harder to reach

poetryblock.poem: than a fortified city,
and quarrels are like the bars of a fortress.

poem.verse: 20From the fruit of a person’s mouth his stomach is satisfied;

poetryblock.poem: he is filled with the product of his lips.

poem.verse: 21Death and life are in the power of the tongue,

poetryblock.poem: and those who love it will eat its fruit.

poem.verse: 22A man who finds a wife finds a good thing

poetryblock.poem: and obtains favour from the Lord.

poem.verse: 23The poor person pleads,

poetryblock.poem: but the rich one answers roughly.

poem.verse: 24One with many friends may be harmed,

poetryblock.poem: but there is a friend who stays closer than a brother.

poem.verse: 1Better a poor person who lives with integrity

poetryblock.poem: than someone who has deceitful lips and is a fool.

poem.verse: 2Even zeal is not good without knowledge,

poetryblock.poem: and the one who acts hastily sins.

poem.verse: 3A person’s own foolishness leads him astray,

poetryblock.poem: yet his heart rages against the Lord.

poem.verse: 4Wealth attracts many friends,

poetryblock.poem: but a poor person is separated from his friend.

poem.verse: 5A false witness will not go unpunished,

poetryblock.poem: and one who utters lies will not escape.

poem.verse: 6Many seek a ruler’s favour,

poetryblock.poem: and everyone is a friend of one who gives gifts.

poem.verse: 7All the brothers of a poor person hate him;

poetryblock.poem: how much more do his friends
keep their distance from him!
He may pursue them with words,
but they are not there.

poem.verse: 8The one who acquires good sense loves himself;

poetryblock.poem: one who safeguards understanding finds success.

poem.verse: 9A false witness will not go unpunished,

poetryblock.poem: and one who utters lies perishes.

poem.verse: 10Luxury is not appropriate for a fool ​– ​

poetryblock.poem: how much less for a slave to rule over princes!

poem.verse: 11A person’s insight gives him patience,

poetryblock.poem: and his virtue is to overlook an offence.

poem.verse: 12A king’s rage is like the roaring of a lion,

poetryblock.poem: but his favour is like dew on the grass.

poem.verse: 13A foolish son is his father’s ruin,

poetryblock.poem: and a wife’s nagging is an endless dripping.

poem.verse: 14A house and wealth are inherited from fathers,

poetryblock.poem: but a prudent wife is from the Lord.

poem.verse: 15Laziness induces deep sleep,

poetryblock.poem: and a lazy person will go hungry.

poem.verse: 16The one who keeps commands preserves himself;

poetryblock.poem: one who disregards his ways will die.

poem.verse: 17Kindness to the poor is a loan to the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: and he will give a reward to the lender.

poem.verse: 18Discipline your son while there is hope;

poetryblock.poem: don’t set your heart on being the cause of his death.

poem.verse: 19A person with intense anger bears the penalty;

poetryblock.poem: if you rescue him, you’ll have to do it again.

poem.verse: 20Listen to counsel and receive instruction

poetryblock.poem: so that you may be wise later in life.

poem.verse: 21Many plans are in a person’s heart,

poetryblock.poem: but the Lord’s decree will prevail.

poem.verse: 22What is desirable in a person is his fidelity;

poetryblock.poem: better to be a poor person than a liar.

poem.verse: 23The fear of the Lord leads to life;

poetryblock.poem: one will sleep at night without danger.

poem.verse: 24The slacker buries his hand in the bowl;

poetryblock.poem: he doesn’t even bring it back to his mouth!

poem.verse: 25Strike a mocker, and the inexperienced learn a lesson;

poetryblock.poem: rebuke the discerning, and he gains knowledge.

poem.verse: 26The one who plunders his father and evicts his mother

poetryblock.poem: is a disgraceful and shameful son.

poem.verse: 27If you stop listening to correction, my son,

poetryblock.poem: you will stray from the words of knowledge.

poem.verse: 28A worthless witness mocks justice,

poetryblock.poem: and a wicked mouth swallows iniquity.

poem.verse: 29Judgements are prepared for mockers,

poetryblock.poem: and beatings for the backs of fools.

poem.verse: 1Wine is a mocker, beer is a brawler;

poetryblock.poem: whoever goes astray because of them is not wise.

poem.verse: 2A king’s terrible wrath is like the roaring of a lion;

poetryblock.poem: anyone who provokes him endangers himself.

poem.verse: 3Honour belongs to the person who ends a dispute,

poetryblock.poem: but any fool can get himself into a quarrel.

poem.verse: 4The slacker does not plough during planting season;

poetryblock.poem: at harvest time he looks, and there is nothing.

poem.verse: 5Counsel in a person’s heart is deep water;

poetryblock.poem: but a person of understanding draws it out.

poem.verse: 6Many a person proclaims his own loyalty,

poetryblock.poem: but who can find a trustworthy person?

poem.verse: 7A righteous person acts with integrity;

poetryblock.poem: his children who come after him will be happy.

poem.verse: 8A king sitting on a throne to judge

poetryblock.poem: separates out all evil with his eyes.

poem.verse: 9Who can say, ‘I have kept my heart pure;

poetryblock.poem: I am cleansed from my sin’?

poem.verse: 10Differing weights and varying measures –

poetryblock.poem: both are detestable to the Lord.

poem.verse: 11Even a young man is known by his actions –

poetryblock.poem: by whether his behaviour is pure and upright.

poem.verse: 12The hearing ear and the seeing eye –

poetryblock.poem: the Lord made them both.

poem.verse: 13Don’t love sleep, or you will become poor;

poetryblock.poem: open your eyes, and you’ll have enough to eat.

poem.verse: 14‘It’s worthless, it’s worthless! ’ the buyer says,

poetryblock.poem: but after he is on his way, he gloats.

poem.verse: 15There is gold and a multitude of jewels,

poetryblock.poem: but knowledgeable lips are a rare treasure.

poem.verse: 16Take his garment,

poetryblock.poem: for he has put up security for a stranger;
get collateral if it is for foreigners.

poem.verse: 17Food gained by fraud is sweet to a person,

poetryblock.poem: but afterwards his mouth is full of gravel.

poem.verse: 18Finalise plans with counsel,

poetryblock.poem: and wage war with sound guidance.

poem.verse: 19The one who reveals secrets is a constant gossip;

poetryblock.poem: avoid someone with a big mouth.

poem.verse: 20Whoever curses his father or mother ​– ​

poetryblock.poem: his lamp will go out in deep darkness.

poem.verse: 21An inheritance gained prematurely

poetryblock.poem: will not be blessed ultimately.

poem.verse: 22Don’t say, ‘I will avenge this evil! ’

poetryblock.poem: Wait on the Lord, and he will rescue you.

poem.verse: 23Differing weights are detestable to the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: and dishonest scales are unfair.

poem.verse: 24Even a courageous person’s steps are determined by the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: so how can anyone understand his own way?

poem.verse: 25It is a trap for anyone to dedicate something rashly

poetryblock.poem: and later to reconsider his vows.

poem.verse: 26A wise king separates out the wicked

poetryblock.poem: and drives the threshing wheel over them.

poem.verse: 27The Lord’s lamp sheds light on a person’s life,

poetryblock.poem: searching the innermost parts.

poem.verse: 28Loyalty and faithfulness guard a king;

poetryblock.poem: through loyalty he maintains his throne.

poem.verse: 29The glory of young men is their strength,

poetryblock.poem: and the splendour of old men is grey hair.

poem.verse: 30Lashes and wounds purge away evil,

poetryblock.poem: and beatings cleanse the innermost parts.

poem.verse: 1A king’s heart is like channelled water in the Lord’s hand:

poetryblock.poem: He directs it wherever he chooses.

poem.verse: 2All a person’s ways seem right to him,

poetryblock.poem: but the Lord weighs hearts.

poem.verse: 3Doing what is righteous and just

poetryblock.poem: is more acceptable to the Lord than sacrifice.

poem.verse: 4The lamp that guides the wicked –

poetryblock.poem: haughty eyes and an arrogant heart ​– ​is sin.

poem.verse: 5The plans of the diligent certainly lead to profit,

poetryblock.poem: but anyone who is reckless certainly becomes poor.

poem.verse: 6Making a fortune through a lying tongue

poetryblock.poem: is a vanishing mist, a pursuit of death.

poem.verse: 7The violence of the wicked sweeps them away

poetryblock.poem: because they refuse to act justly.

poem.verse: 8A guilty one’s conduct is crooked,

poetryblock.poem: but the behaviour of the innocent is upright.

poem.verse: 9Better to live on the corner of a roof

poetryblock.poem: than to share a house with a nagging wife.

poem.verse: 10A wicked person desires evil;

poetryblock.poem: he has no consideration for his neighbour.

poem.verse: 11When a mocker is punished,

poetryblock.poem: the inexperienced become wiser;
when one teaches a wise man,
he acquires knowledge.

poem.verse: 12The Righteous One considers the house of the wicked;

poetryblock.poem: he brings the wicked to ruin.

poem.verse: 13The one who shuts his ears to the cry of the poor

poetryblock.poem: will himself also call out and not be answered.

poem.verse: 14A secret gift soothes anger,

poetryblock.poem: and a covert bribe, fierce rage.

poem.verse: 15Justice executed is a joy to the righteous

poetryblock.poem: but a terror to evildoers.

poem.verse: 16The person who strays from the way of prudence

poetryblock.poem: will come to rest in the assembly of the departed spirits.

poem.verse: 17The one who loves pleasure will become poor;

poetryblock.poem: whoever loves wine and oil will not get rich.

poem.verse: 18The wicked are a ransom for the righteous,

poetryblock.poem: and the treacherous, for the upright.

poem.verse: 19Better to live in a wilderness

poetryblock.poem: than with a nagging and hot-tempered wife.

poem.verse: 20Precious treasure and oil are in the dwelling of a wise person,

poetryblock.poem: but a fool consumes them.

poem.verse: 21The one who pursues righteousness and faithful love

poetryblock.poem: will find life, righteousness, and honour.

poem.verse: 22A wise person went up against a city of warriors

poetryblock.poem: and brought down its secure fortress.

poem.verse: 23The one who guards his mouth and tongue

poetryblock.poem: keeps himself out of trouble.

poem.verse: 24The arrogant and proud person, named ‘Mocker,’

poetryblock.poem: acts with excessive arrogance.

poem.verse: 25A slacker’s craving will kill him

poetryblock.poem: because his hands refuse to work.

poem.verse: 26He is filled with craving all day long,

poetryblock.poem: but the righteous give and don’t hold back.

poem.verse: 27The sacrifice of a wicked person is detestable ​–

poetryblock.poem: how much more so
when he brings it with ulterior motives!

poem.verse: 28A lying witness will perish,

poetryblock.poem: but the one who listens will speak successfully.

poem.verse: 29A wicked person puts on a bold face,

poetryblock.poem: but the upright one considers his way.

poem.verse: 30No wisdom, no understanding, and no counsel

poetryblock.poem: will prevail against the Lord.

poem.verse: 31A horse is prepared for the day of battle,

poetryblock.poem: but victory comes from the Lord.

poem.verse: 1A good name is to be chosen over great wealth;

poetryblock.poem: favour is better than silver and gold.

poem.verse: 2Rich and poor have this in common:

poetryblock.poem: the Lord makes them all.

poem.verse: 3A sensible person sees danger and takes cover,

poetryblock.poem: but the inexperienced keep going and are punished.

poem.verse: 4Humility, the fear of the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: results in wealth, honour, and life.

poem.verse: 5There are thorns and snares on the way of the crooked;

poetryblock.poem: the one who guards himself stays far from them.

poem.verse: 6Start a youth out on his way;

poetryblock.poem: even when he grows old he will not depart from it.

poem.verse: 7The rich rule over the poor,

poetryblock.poem: and the borrower is a slave to the lender.

poem.verse: 8The one who sows injustice will reap disaster,

poetryblock.poem: and the rod of his fury will be destroyed.

poem.verse: 9A generous person will be blessed,

poetryblock.poem: for he shares his food with the poor.

poem.verse: 10Drive out a mocker, and conflict goes too;

poetryblock.poem: then quarrelling and dishonour will cease.

poem.verse: 11The one who loves a pure heart

poetryblock.poem: and gracious lips ​– ​the king is his friend.

poem.verse: 12The Lord’s eyes keep watch over knowledge,

poetryblock.poem: but he overthrows the words of the treacherous.

poem.verse: 13The slacker says, ‘There’s a lion outside!

poetryblock.poem: I’ll be killed in the public square! ’

poem.verse: 14The mouth of the forbidden woman is a deep pit;

poetryblock.poem: a man cursed by the Lord will fall into it.

poem.verse: 15Foolishness is bound to the heart of a youth;

poetryblock.poem: a rod of discipline will separate it from him.

poem.verse: 16Oppressing the poor to enrich oneself,

poetryblock.poem: and giving to the rich ​– ​both lead only to poverty.

poem.verse: 17Listen closely, pay attention to the words of the wise,

poetryblock.poem: and apply your mind to my knowledge.

poem.verse: 18For it is pleasing if you keep them within you

poetryblock.poem: and if they are constantly on your lips.

poem.verse: 19I have instructed you today ​– ​even you –

poetryblock.poem: so that your confidence may be in the Lord.

poem.verse: 20Haven’t I written for you thirty sayings

poetryblock.poem: about counsel and knowledge,

poem.verse: 21in order to teach you true and reliable words,

poetryblock.poem: so that you may give a dependable report
to those who sent you?

poem.verse: 22Don’t rob a poor person because he is poor,

poetryblock.poem: and don’t crush the oppressed at the city gate,

poem.verse: 23for the Lord will champion their cause

poetryblock.poem: and will plunder those who plunder them.

poem.verse: 24Don’t make friends with an angry person,

poetryblock.poem: and don’t be a companion of a hot-tempered one,

poem.verse: 25or you will learn his ways

poetryblock.poem: and entangle yourself in a snare.

poem.verse: 26Don’t be one of those who enter agreements,

poetryblock.poem: who put up security for loans.

poem.verse: 27If you have nothing with which to pay,

poetryblock.poem: even your bed will be taken from under you.

poem.verse: 28Don’t move an ancient boundary marker

poetryblock.poem: that your ancestors set up.

poem.verse: 29Do you see a person skilled in his work?

poetryblock.poem: He will stand in the presence of kings.
He will not stand in the presence of the unknown.

poem.verse: 1When you sit down to dine with a ruler,

poetryblock.poem: consider carefully what is before you,

poem.verse: 2and put a knife to your throat

poetryblock.poem: if you have a big appetite;

poem.verse: 3don’t desire his delicacies,

poetryblock.poem: for that food is deceptive.

poem.verse: 4Don’t wear yourself out to get rich;

poetryblock.poem: because you know better, stop!

poem.verse: 5As soon as your eyes fly to it, it disappears,

poetryblock.poem: for it makes wings for itself
and flies like an eagle to the sky.

poem.verse: 6Don’t eat a stingy person’s bread,

poetryblock.poem: and don’t desire his delicacies,

poem.verse: 7for it’s like someone calculating inwardly.

poetryblock.poem: ‘Eat and drink,’ he says to you,
but his heart is not with you.

poem.verse: 8You will vomit the little you’ve eaten

poetryblock.poem: and waste your pleasant words.

poem.verse: 9Don’t speak to a fool,

poetryblock.poem: for he will despise the insight of your words.

poem.verse: 10Don’t move an ancient boundary marker,

poetryblock.poem: and don’t encroach on the fields of the fatherless,

poem.verse: 11for their Redeemer is strong,

poetryblock.poem: and he will champion their cause against you.

poem.verse: 12Apply yourself to discipline

poetryblock.poem: and listen to words of knowledge.

poem.verse: 13Don’t withhold discipline from a youth;

poetryblock.poem: if you punish him with a rod, he will not die.

poem.verse: 14Punish him with a rod,

poetryblock.poem: and you will rescue his life from Sheol.

poem.verse: 15My son, if your heart is wise,

poetryblock.poem: my heart will indeed rejoice.

poem.verse: 16My innermost being will celebrate

poetryblock.poem: when your lips say what is right.

poem.verse: 17Don’t let your heart envy sinners;

poetryblock.poem: instead, always fear the Lord.

poem.verse: 18For then you will have a future,

poetryblock.poem: and your hope will not be dashed.

poem.verse: 19Listen, my son, and be wise;

poetryblock.poem: keep your mind on the right course.

poem.verse: 20Don’t associate with those who drink too much wine

poetryblock.poem: or with those who gorge themselves on meat.

poem.verse: 21For the drunkard and the glutton will become poor,

poetryblock.poem: and grogginess will clothe them in rags.

poem.verse: 22Listen to your father who gave you life,

poetryblock.poem: and don’t despise your mother when she is old.

poem.verse: 23Buy ​– ​and do not sell ​– ​truth,

poetryblock.poem: wisdom, instruction, and understanding.

poem.verse: 24The father of a righteous son will rejoice greatly,

poetryblock.poem: and one who fathers a wise son will delight in him.

poem.verse: 25Let your father and mother have joy,

poetryblock.poem: and let her who gave birth to you rejoice.

poem.verse: 26My son, give me your heart,

poetryblock.poem: and let your eyes observe my ways.

poem.verse: 27For a prostitute is a deep pit,

poetryblock.poem: and a wayward woman is a narrow well;

poem.verse: 28indeed, she sets an ambush like a robber

poetryblock.poem: and increases the number of unfaithful people.

poem.verse: 29Who has woe? Who has sorrow?

poetryblock.poem: Who has conflicts? Who has complaints?
Who has wounds for no reason?
Who has red eyes?

poem.verse: 30Those who linger over wine;

poetryblock.poem: those who go looking for mixed wine.

poem.verse: 31Don’t gaze at wine because it is red,

poetryblock.poem: because it gleams in the cup
and goes down smoothly.

poem.verse: 32In the end it bites like a snake

poetryblock.poem: and stings like a viper.

poem.verse: 33Your eyes will see strange things,

poetryblock.poem: and you will say absurd things.

poem.verse: 34You’ll be like someone sleeping out at sea

poetryblock.poem: or lying down on the top of a ship’s mast.

poem.verse: 35‘They struck me, but I feel no pain!

poetryblock.poem: They beat me, but I didn’t know it!
When will I wake up?
I’ll look for another drink.’

poem.verse: 1Don’t envy the evil

poetryblock.poem: or desire to be with them,

poem.verse: 2for their hearts plan violence,

poetryblock.poem: and their words stir up trouble.

poem.verse: 3A house is built by wisdom,

poetryblock.poem: and it is established by understanding;

poem.verse: 4by knowledge the rooms are filled

poetryblock.poem: with every precious and beautiful treasure.

poem.verse: 5A wise warrior is better than a strong one,

poetryblock.poem: and a man of knowledge than one of strength;

poem.verse: 6for you should wage war with sound guidance –

poetryblock.poem: victory comes with many counsellors.

poem.verse: 7Wisdom is inaccessible to a fool;

poetryblock.poem: he does not open his mouth at the city gate.

poem.verse: 8The one who plots evil

poetryblock.poem: will be called a schemer.

poem.verse: 9A foolish scheme is sin,

poetryblock.poem: and a mocker is detestable to people.

poem.verse: 10If you do nothing in a difficult time,

poetryblock.poem: your strength is limited.

poem.verse: 11Rescue those being taken off to death,

poetryblock.poem: and save those stumbling towards slaughter.

poem.verse: 12If you say, ‘But we didn’t know about this,’

poetryblock.poem: won’t he who weighs hearts consider it?
Won’t he who protects your life know?
Won’t he repay a person according to his work?

poem.verse: 13Eat honey, my son, for it is good,

poetryblock.poem: and the honeycomb is sweet to your palate;

poem.verse: 14realise that wisdom is the same for you.

poetryblock.poem: If you find it, you will have a future,
and your hope will never fade.

poem.verse: 15Don’t set an ambush, you wicked one,

poetryblock.poem: at the camp of the righteous man;
