don’t destroy his dwelling.

poem.verse: 16Though a righteous person falls seven times,

poetryblock.poem: he will get up,
but the wicked will stumble into ruin.

poem.verse: 17Don’t gloat when your enemy falls,

poetryblock.poem: and don’t let your heart rejoice when he stumbles,

poem.verse: 18or the Lord will see, be displeased,

poetryblock.poem: and turn his wrath away from him.

poem.verse: 19Don’t be agitated by evildoers,

poetryblock.poem: and don’t envy the wicked.

poem.verse: 20For the evil have no future;

poetryblock.poem: the lamp of the wicked will be put out.

poem.verse: 21My son, fear the Lord, as well as the king,

poetryblock.poem: and don’t associate with rebels,

poem.verse: 22for destruction will come suddenly from them;

poetryblock.poem: who knows what distress these two can bring?

poem.verse: 23These sayings also belong to the wise:

poetryblock.poem: It is not good to show partiality in judgement.

poem.verse: 24Whoever says to the guilty, ‘You are innocent’ –

poetryblock.poem: peoples will curse him, and nations will denounce him;

poem.verse: 25but it will go well with those who convict the guilty,

poetryblock.poem: and a generous blessing will come to them.

poem.verse: 26He who gives an honest answer

poetryblock.poem: gives a kiss on the lips.

poem.verse: 27Complete your outdoor work, and prepare your field;

poetryblock.poem: afterwards, build your house.

poem.verse: 28Don’t testify against your neighbour without cause.

poetryblock.poem: Don’t deceive with your lips.

poem.verse: 29Don’t say, ‘I’ll do to him what he did to me;

poetryblock.poem: I’ll repay the man for what he has done.’

poem.verse: 30I went by the field of a slacker

poetryblock.poem: and by the vineyard of one lacking sense.

poem.verse: 31Thistles had come up everywhere,

poetryblock.poem: weeds covered the ground,
and the stone wall was ruined.

poem.verse: 32I saw, and took it to heart;

poetryblock.poem: I looked, and received instruction:

poem.verse: 33a little sleep, a little slumber,

poetryblock.poem: a little folding of the arms to rest,

poem.verse: 34and your poverty will come like a robber,

poetryblock.poem: and your need, like a bandit.

poem.verse: 1These too are proverbs of Solomon,

poetryblock.poem: which the men of King Hezekiah of Judah copied.

poem.verse: 2It is the glory of God to conceal a matter

poetryblock.poem: and the glory of kings to investigate a matter.

poem.verse: 3As the heavens are high and the earth is deep,

poetryblock.poem: so the hearts of kings cannot be investigated.

poem.verse: 4Remove impurities from silver,

poetryblock.poem: and material will be produced for a silversmith.

poem.verse: 5Remove the wicked from the king’s presence,

poetryblock.poem: and his throne will be established in righteousness.

poem.verse: 6Don’t boast about yourself before the king,

poetryblock.poem: and don’t stand in the place of the great;

poem.verse: 7for it is better for him to say to you, ‘Come up here! ’

poetryblock.poem: than to demote you in plain view of a noble.

poem.verse: 8Don’t take a matter to court hastily.

poetryblock.poem: Otherwise, what will you do afterwards
if your opponent humiliates you?

poem.verse: 9Make your case with your opponent

poetryblock.poem: without revealing another’s secret;

poem.verse: 10otherwise, the one who hears will disgrace you,

poetryblock.poem: and you’ll never live it down.

poem.verse: 11A word spoken at the right time

poetryblock.poem: is like gold apples in silver settings.

poem.verse: 12A wise correction to a receptive ear

poetryblock.poem: is like a gold ring or an ornament of gold.

poem.verse: 13To those who send him, a trustworthy envoy

poetryblock.poem: is like the coolness of snow on a harvest day;
he refreshes the life of his masters.

poem.verse: 14The one who boasts about a gift that does not exist

poetryblock.poem: is like clouds and wind without rain.

poem.verse: 15A ruler can be persuaded through patience,

poetryblock.poem: and a gentle tongue can break a bone.

poem.verse: 16If you find honey, eat only what you need;

poetryblock.poem: otherwise, you’ll get sick from it and vomit.

poem.verse: 17Seldom set foot in your neighbour’s house;

poetryblock.poem: otherwise, he’ll get sick of you and hate you.

poem.verse: 18A person giving false testimony against his neighbour

poetryblock.poem: is like a club, a sword, or a sharp arrow.

poem.verse: 19Trusting an unreliable person in a difficult time

poetryblock.poem: is like a rotten tooth or a faltering foot.

poem.verse: 20Singing songs to a troubled heart

poetryblock.poem: is like taking off clothing on a cold day
or like pouring vinegar on soda.

poem.verse: 21If your enemy is hungry, give him food to eat,

poetryblock.poem: and if he is thirsty, give him water to drink,

poem.verse: 22for you will heap burning coals on his head,

poetryblock.poem: and the Lord will reward you.

poem.verse: 23The north wind produces rain,

poetryblock.poem: and a backbiting tongue, angry looks.

poem.verse: 24Better to live on the corner of a roof

poetryblock.poem: than to share a house with a nagging wife.

poem.verse: 25Good news from a distant land

poetryblock.poem: is like cold water to a parched throat.

poem.verse: 26A righteous person who yields to the wicked

poetryblock.poem: is like a muddied spring or a polluted well.

poem.verse: 27It is not good to eat too much honey

poetryblock.poem: or to seek glory after glory.

poem.verse: 28A person who does not control his temper

poetryblock.poem: is like a city whose wall is broken down.

poem.verse: 1Like snow in summer and rain at harvest,

poetryblock.poem: honour is inappropriate for a fool.

poem.verse: 2Like a flitting sparrow or a fluttering swallow,

poetryblock.poem: an undeserved curse goes nowhere.

poem.verse: 3A whip for the horse, a bridle for the donkey,

poetryblock.poem: and a rod for the backs of fools.

poem.verse: 4Don’t answer a fool according to his foolishness

poetryblock.poem: or you’ll be like him yourself.

poem.verse: 5Answer a fool according to his foolishness

poetryblock.poem: or he’ll become wise in his own eyes.

poem.verse: 6The one who sends a message by a fool’s hand

poetryblock.poem: cuts off his own feet and drinks violence.

poem.verse: 7A proverb in the mouth of a fool

poetryblock.poem: is like lame legs that hang limp.

poem.verse: 8Giving honour to a fool

poetryblock.poem: is like binding a stone in a sling.

poem.verse: 9A proverb in the mouth of a fool

poetryblock.poem: is like a stick with thorns,
brandished by the hand of a drunkard.

poem.verse: 10The one who hires a fool or who hires those passing by

poetryblock.poem: is like an archer who wounds everyone indiscriminately.

poem.verse: 11As a dog returns to its vomit,

poetryblock.poem: so also a fool repeats his foolishness.

poem.verse: 12Do you see a person who is wise in his own eyes?

poetryblock.poem: There is more hope for a fool than for him.

poem.verse: 13The slacker says, ‘There’s a lion in the road –

poetryblock.poem: a lion in the public square! ’

poem.verse: 14A door turns on its hinges,

poetryblock.poem: and a slacker, on his bed.

poem.verse: 15The slacker buries his hand in the bowl;

poetryblock.poem: he is too weary to bring it to his mouth!

poem.verse: 16In his own eyes, a slacker is wiser

poetryblock.poem: than seven who can answer sensibly.

poem.verse: 17A person who is passing by and meddles in a quarrel that’s not his

poetryblock.poem: is like one who grabs a dog by the ears.

poem.verse: 18Like a madman who throws flaming darts and deadly arrows,
19so is the person who deceives his neighbour

poetryblock.poem: and says, ‘I was only joking! ’

poem.verse: 20Without wood, fire goes out;

poetryblock.poem: without a gossip, conflict dies down.

poem.verse: 21As charcoal for embers and wood for fire,

poetryblock.poem: so is a quarrelsome person for kindling strife.

poem.verse: 22A gossip’s words are like delicacies

poetryblock.poem: that go down to one’s innermost being.

poem.verse: 23Smooth lips with an evil heart

poetryblock.poem: are like glaze on an earthen vessel.

poem.verse: 24A hateful person disguises himself with his speech

poetryblock.poem: and harbours deceit within.

poem.verse: 25When he speaks graciously, don’t believe him,

poetryblock.poem: for there are seven detestable things in his heart.

poem.verse: 26Though his hatred is concealed by deception,

poetryblock.poem: his evil will be revealed in the assembly.

poem.verse: 27The one who digs a pit will fall into it,

poetryblock.poem: and whoever rolls a stone –
it will come back on him.

poem.verse: 28A lying tongue hates those it crushes,

poetryblock.poem: and a flattering mouth causes ruin.

poem.verse: 1Don’t boast about tomorrow,

poetryblock.poem: for you don’t know what a day might bring.

poem.verse: 2Let another praise you, and not your own mouth –

poetryblock.poem: a stranger, and not your own lips.

poem.verse: 3A stone is heavy, and sand a burden,

poetryblock.poem: but aggravation from a fool outweighs them both.

poem.verse: 4Fury is cruel, and anger a flood,

poetryblock.poem: but who can withstand jealousy?

poem.verse: 5Better an open reprimand

poetryblock.poem: than concealed love.

poem.verse: 6The wounds of a friend are trustworthy,

poetryblock.poem: but the kisses of an enemy are excessive.

poem.verse: 7A person who is full tramples on a honeycomb,

poetryblock.poem: but to a hungry person, any bitter thing is sweet.

poem.verse: 8Anyone wandering from his home

poetryblock.poem: is like a bird wandering from its nest.

poem.verse: 9Oil and incense bring joy to the heart,

poetryblock.poem: and the sweetness of a friend is better than self-counsel.

poem.verse: 10Don’t abandon your friend or your father’s friend,

poetryblock.poem: and don’t go to your brother’s house
in your time of calamity;
better a neighbour nearby than a brother far away.

poem.verse: 11Be wise, my son, and bring my heart joy,

poetryblock.poem: so that I can answer anyone who taunts me.

poem.verse: 12A sensible person sees danger and takes cover;

poetryblock.poem: the inexperienced keep going and are punished.

poem.verse: 13Take his garment,

poetryblock.poem: for he has put up security for a stranger;
get collateral if it is for foreigners.

poem.verse: 14If one blesses his neighbour

poetryblock.poem: with a loud voice early in the morning,
it will be counted as a curse to him.

poem.verse: 15An endless dripping on a rainy day

poetryblock.poem: and a nagging wife are alike;

poem.verse: 16the one who controls her controls the wind

poetryblock.poem: and grasps oil with his right hand.

poem.verse: 17Iron sharpens iron,

poetryblock.poem: and one person sharpens another.

poem.verse: 18Whoever tends a fig tree will eat its fruit,

poetryblock.poem: and whoever looks after his master will be honoured.

poem.verse: 19As water reflects the face,

poetryblock.poem: so the heart reflects the person.

poem.verse: 20Sheol and Abaddon are never satisfied,

poetryblock.poem: and people’s eyes are never satisfied.

poem.verse: 21As a crucible refines silver,

poetryblock.poem: and a smelter refines gold,
so a person should refine his praise.

poem.verse: 22Though you grind a fool

poetryblock.poem: in a mortar with a pestle along with grain,
you will not separate his foolishness from him.

poem.verse: 23Know well the condition of your flock,

poetryblock.poem: and pay attention to your herds,

poem.verse: 24for wealth is not for ever;

poetryblock.poem: not even a crown lasts for all time.

poem.verse: 25When hay is removed and new growth appears

poetryblock.poem: and the corn from the hills is gathered in,

poem.verse: 26lambs will provide your clothing,

poetryblock.poem: and goats, the price of a field;

poem.verse: 27there will be enough goat’s milk for your food –

poetryblock.poem: food for your household
and nourishment for your female servants.

poem.verse: 1The wicked flee when no one is pursuing them,

poetryblock.poem: but the righteous are as bold as a lion.

poem.verse: 2When a land is in rebellion, it has many rulers,

poetryblock.poem: but with a discerning and knowledgeable person, it endures.

poem.verse: 3A destitute leader who oppresses the poor

poetryblock.poem: is like a driving rain that leaves no food.

poem.verse: 4Those who reject the law praise the wicked,

poetryblock.poem: but those who keep the law pit themselves against them.

poem.verse: 5The evil do not understand justice,

poetryblock.poem: but those who seek the Lord understand everything.

poem.verse: 6Better the poor person who lives with integrity

poetryblock.poem: than the rich one who distorts right and wrong.

poem.verse: 7A discerning son keeps the law,

poetryblock.poem: but a companion of gluttons humiliates his father.

poem.verse: 8Whoever increases his wealth through excessive interest

poetryblock.poem: collects it for one who is kind to the poor.

poem.verse: 9Anyone who turns his ear away from hearing the law –

poetryblock.poem: even his prayer is detestable.

poem.verse: 10The one who leads the upright into an evil way

poetryblock.poem: will fall into his own pit,
but the blameless will inherit what is good.

poem.verse: 11A rich person is wise in his own eyes,

poetryblock.poem: but a poor one who has discernment sees through him.

poem.verse: 12When the righteous triumph,

poetryblock.poem: there is great rejoicing,
but when the wicked come to power,
people hide.

poem.verse: 13The one who conceals his sins

poetryblock.poem: will not prosper,
but whoever confesses and renounces them
will find mercy.

poem.verse: 14Happy is the one who is always reverent,

poetryblock.poem: but one who hardens his heart falls into trouble.

poem.verse: 15A wicked ruler over a helpless people

poetryblock.poem: is like a roaring lion or a charging bear.

poem.verse: 16A leader who lacks understanding

poetryblock.poem: is very oppressive,
but one who hates dishonest profit
prolongs his life.

poem.verse: 17Someone burdened by bloodguilt

poetryblock.poem: will be a fugitive until death.
Let no one help him.

poem.verse: 18The one who lives with integrity will be helped,

poetryblock.poem: but one who distorts right and wrong
will suddenly fall.

poem.verse: 19The one who works his land

poetryblock.poem: will have plenty of food,
but whoever chases fantasies
will have his fill of poverty.

poem.verse: 20A faithful person will have many blessings,

poetryblock.poem: but one in a hurry to get rich
will not go unpunished.

poem.verse: 21It is not good to show partiality –

poetryblock.poem: yet even a courageous person may sin for a piece of bread.

poem.verse: 22A greedy one is in a hurry for wealth;

poetryblock.poem: he doesn’t know that poverty will come to him.

poem.verse: 23One who rebukes a person will later find more favour

poetryblock.poem: than one who flatters with his tongue.

poem.verse: 24The one who robs his father or mother

poetryblock.poem: and says, ‘That’s no sin,’
is a companion to a person who destroys.

poem.verse: 25A greedy person stirs up conflict,

poetryblock.poem: but whoever trusts in the Lord will prosper.

poem.verse: 26The one who trusts in himself is a fool,

poetryblock.poem: but one who walks in wisdom will be safe.

poem.verse: 27The one who gives to the poor

poetryblock.poem: will not be in need,
but one who turns his eyes away
will receive many curses.

poem.verse: 28When the wicked come to power,

poetryblock.poem: people hide,
but when they are destroyed,
the righteous flourish.

poem.verse: 1One who becomes stiff-necked,

poetryblock.poem: after many reprimands
will be shattered instantly –
beyond recovery.

poem.verse: 2When the righteous flourish, the people rejoice,

poetryblock.poem: but when the wicked rule, people groan.

poem.verse: 3A man who loves wisdom brings joy to his father,

poetryblock.poem: but one who consorts with prostitutes destroys his wealth.

poem.verse: 4By justice a king brings stability to a land,

poetryblock.poem: but a person who demands ‘contributions’
demolishes it.

poem.verse: 5A person who flatters his neighbour

poetryblock.poem: spreads a net for his feet.

poem.verse: 6An evil person is caught by sin,

poetryblock.poem: but the righteous one sings and rejoices.

poem.verse: 7The righteous person knows the rights of the poor,

poetryblock.poem: but the wicked one does not understand these concerns.

poem.verse: 8Mockers inflame a city,

poetryblock.poem: but the wise turn away anger.

poem.verse: 9If a wise person goes to court with a fool,

poetryblock.poem: there will be ranting and raving but no resolution.

poem.verse: 10Bloodthirsty men hate an honest person,

poetryblock.poem: but the upright care about him.

poem.verse: 11A fool gives full vent to his anger,

poetryblock.poem: but a wise person holds it in check.

poem.verse: 12If a ruler listens to lies,

poetryblock.poem: all his officials will be wicked.

poem.verse: 13The poor and the oppressor have this in common:

poetryblock.poem: the Lord gives light to the eyes of both.

poem.verse: 14A king who judges the poor with fairness –

poetryblock.poem: his throne will be established for ever.

poem.verse: 15A rod of correction imparts wisdom,

poetryblock.poem: but a youth left to himself
is a disgrace to his mother.

poem.verse: 16When the wicked increase, rebellion increases,

poetryblock.poem: but the righteous will see their downfall.

poem.verse: 17Discipline your child, and it will bring you peace of mind

poetryblock.poem: and give you delight.

poem.verse: 18Without revelation people run wild,

poetryblock.poem: but one who follows divine instruction will be happy.

poem.verse: 19A servant cannot be disciplined by words;

poetryblock.poem: though he understands, he doesn’t respond.

poem.verse: 20Do you see someone who speaks too soon?

poetryblock.poem: There is more hope for a fool than for him.

poem.verse: 21A servant pampered from his youth

poetryblock.poem: will become arrogant later on.

poem.verse: 22An angry person stirs up conflict,

poetryblock.poem: and a hot-tempered one increases rebellion.

poem.verse: 23A person’s pride will humble him,

poetryblock.poem: but a humble spirit will gain honour.

poem.verse: 24To be a thief’s partner is to hate oneself;

poetryblock.poem: he hears the curse but will not testify.

poem.verse: 25The fear of mankind is a snare,

poetryblock.poem: but the one who trusts in the Lord is protected.

poem.verse: 26Many desire a ruler’s favour,

poetryblock.poem: but a person receives justice from the Lord.

poem.verse: 27An unjust person is detestable to the righteous,

poetryblock.poem: and one whose way is upright
is detestable to the wicked.

poem.verse: 1The words of Agur son of Jakeh. The pronouncement.

poetryblock.poem: The man’s oration to Ithiel, to Ithiel and Ucal:

poem.verse: 2I am more stupid than any other person,

poetryblock.poem: and I lack a human’s ability to understand.

poem.verse: 3I have not gained wisdom,

poetryblock.poem: and I have no knowledge of the Holy One.

poem.verse: 4Who has gone up to heaven and come down?

poetryblock.poem: Who has gathered the wind in his hands?
Who has bound up the waters in a cloak?
Who has established all the ends of the earth?
What is his name,
and what is the name of his son –
if you know?

poem.verse: 5Every word of God is pure;

poetryblock.poem: he is a shield to those who take refuge in him.

poem.verse: 6Don’t add to his words,

poetryblock.poem: or he will rebuke you, and you will be proved a liar.

poem.verse: 7Two things I ask of you;

poetryblock.poem: don’t deny them to me before I die:

poem.verse: 8Keep falsehood and deceitful words far from me.

poetryblock.poem: Give me neither poverty nor wealth;
feed me with the food I need.

poem.verse: 9Otherwise, I might have too much

poetryblock.poem: and deny you, saying, ‘Who is the Lord? ’
or I might have nothing and steal,
profaning the name of my God.

poem.verse: 10Don’t slander a servant to his master

poetryblock.poem: or he will curse you, and you will become guilty.

poem.verse: 11There is a generation that curses its father

poetryblock.poem: and does not bless its mother.

poem.verse: 12There is a generation that is pure in its own eyes,

poetryblock.poem: yet is not washed from its filth.

poem.verse: 13There is a generation ​– ​how haughty its eyes

poetryblock.poem: and pretentious its looks.

poem.verse: 14There is a generation whose teeth are swords,

poetryblock.poem: whose fangs are knives,
devouring the oppressed from the land
and the needy from among mankind.

poem.verse: 15The leech has two daughters: ‘Give, Give! ’

poetryblock.poem: Three things are never satisfied;
four never say, ‘Enough! ’:

poem.verse: 16Sheol; a childless womb;

poetryblock.poem: earth, which is never satisfied with water;
and fire, which never says, ‘Enough! ’

poem.verse: 17As for the eye that ridicules a father

poetryblock.poem: and despises obedience to a mother,
may ravens of the valley pluck it out
and young vultures eat it.

poem.verse: 18Three things are too wondrous for me;

poetryblock.poem: four I can’t understand:

poem.verse: 19the way of an eagle in the sky,

poetryblock.poem: the way of a snake on a rock,
the way of a ship at sea,
and the way of a man with a young woman.

poem.verse: 20This is the way of an adulteress:

poetryblock.poem: she eats and wipes her mouth
and says, ‘I’ve done nothing wrong.’

poem.verse: 21The earth trembles under three things;

poetryblock.poem: it cannot bear up under four:

poem.verse: 22a servant when he becomes king,

poetryblock.poem: a fool when he is stuffed with food,

poem.verse: 23an unloved woman when she marries,

poetryblock.poem: and a servant girl when she ousts her queen.

poem.verse: 24Four things on earth are small,

poetryblock.poem: yet they are extremely wise:

poem.verse: 25ants are not a strong people,

poetryblock.poem: yet they store up their food in the summer;

poem.verse: 26hyraxes are not a mighty people,

poetryblock.poem: yet they make their homes in the cliffs;

poem.verse: 27locusts have no king,

poetryblock.poem: yet all of them march in ranks;

poem.verse: 28a lizard can be caught in your hands,

poetryblock.poem: yet it lives in kings’ palaces.

poem.verse: 29Three things are stately in their stride;

poetryblock.poem: four are stately in their walk:

poem.verse: 30a lion, which is mightiest among beasts

poetryblock.poem: and doesn’t retreat before anything;

poem.verse: 31a strutting cockerel; a goat;

poetryblock.poem: and a king at the head of his army.

poem.verse: 32If you have been foolish by exalting yourself

poetryblock.poem: or if you’ve been scheming,
put your hand over your mouth.

poem.verse: 33For the churning of milk produces butter,

poetryblock.poem: and twisting a nose draws blood,
and stirring up anger produces strife.

poem.verse: 1The words of King Lemuel,

poetryblock.poem: a pronouncement that his mother taught him:

poem.verse: 2What should I say, my son?

poetryblock.poem: What, son of my womb?
What, son of my vows?

poem.verse: 3Don’t spend your energy on women

poetryblock.poem: or your efforts on those who destroy kings.

poem.verse: 4It is not for kings, Lemuel,

poetryblock.poem: it is not for kings to drink wine
or for rulers to desire beer.

poem.verse: 5Otherwise, he will drink,

poetryblock.poem: forget what is decreed,
and pervert justice for all the oppressed.

poem.verse: 6Give beer to one who is dying

poetryblock.poem: and wine to one whose life is bitter.

poem.verse: 7Let him drink so that he can forget his poverty

poetryblock.poem: and remember his trouble no more.

poem.verse: 8Speak up for those who have no voice,

poetryblock.poem: for the justice of all who are dispossessed.

poem.verse: 9Speak up, judge righteously,

poetryblock.poem: and defend the cause of the oppressed and needy.

chapter.head1: In Praise of a Wife of Noble Character

poem.verse: 10Who can find a wife of noble character?

poetryblock.poem: She is far more precious than jewels.

poem.verse: 11The heart of her husband trusts in her,

poetryblock.poem: and he will not lack anything good.

poem.verse: 12She rewards him with good, not evil,

poetryblock.poem: all the days of her life.

poem.verse: 13She selects wool and flax

poetryblock.poem: and works with willing hands.

poem.verse: 14She is like the merchant ships,

poetryblock.poem: bringing her food from far away.

poem.verse: 15She rises while it is still night

poetryblock.poem: and provides food for her household
and portions for her female servants.

poem.verse: 16She evaluates a field and buys it;

poetryblock.poem: she plants a vineyard with her earnings.

poem.verse: 17She draws on her strength

poetryblock.poem: and reveals that her arms are strong.

poem.verse: 18She sees that her profits are good,

poetryblock.poem: and her lamp never goes out at night.

poem.verse: 19She extends her hands to the spinning staff,

poetryblock.poem: and her hands hold the spindle.

poem.verse: 20Her hands reach out to the poor,

poetryblock.poem: and she extends her hands to the needy.

poem.verse: 21She is not afraid for her household when it snows,

poetryblock.poem: for all in her household are doubly clothed.

poem.verse: 22She makes her own bed coverings;

poetryblock.poem: her clothing is fine linen and purple.

poem.verse: 23Her husband is known at the city gates,

poetryblock.poem: where he sits among the elders of the land.

poem.verse: 24She makes and sells linen garments;

poetryblock.poem: she delivers belts to the merchants.

poem.verse: 25Strength and honour are her clothing,

poetryblock.poem: and she can laugh at the time to come.

poem.verse: 26Her mouth speaks wisdom,

poetryblock.poem: and loving instruction is on her tongue.

poem.verse: 27She watches over the activities of her household

poetryblock.poem: and is never idle.

poem.verse: 28Her children rise up and call her blessed;

poetryblock.poem: her husband also praises her:

poem.verse: 29‘Many women have done noble deeds,

poetryblock.poem: but you surpass them all! ’

poem.verse: 30Charm is deceptive and beauty is fleeting,

poetryblock.poem: but a woman who fears the Lord will be praised.

poem.verse: 31Give her the reward of her labour,

poetryblock.poem: and let her works praise her at the city gates.
